number of helpful: 90 of 108 people (83%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
												Zeno Clash is a beat'em up style fighting game with a dash of first person shooter added into the mix. This game uses Valve's Source engine and was released in April 2009. The xBox got it's version a year later in 2010, but for some reason, got a "Ultimate Edition" with content that cannot be accessed on the PC version.  You play as a young warrior named Ghat, and you are on the run from your family as you have accidentally killed your father in an explosion. You have a female companion by the name of Deadra who helps save Ghat along the way. The gameplay is whilst looks like it is a very generic fighting game, it feels different. I couldn't quite put my finger on it, but the gameplay seemed a little off to begin with. The tutorial gives a very good introduction into the basics of fighting and dodging, as well as helps you along the way with controls and early combos.  You have the usual quick attacks, powerful attacks, dodges, and blocks as you would expect. Zeno Clash also adds in a little gun combat too, which again, almost feels a little bit off. There is no auto reload on the weapons, which is not always a bad thing, but most fps style games now days at least auto reload once you have emptied your round/clip.  You also cannot fire you run unless you are looking down the scope of it; meaning you will probably end up throwing your weapon around a lot like I did as I was just trying to shoot from the hip. Every level is essentially a fight scene, you have a set amount of opponents which are introduced at the start of each stage, and the aim is to kill them, simples. Zeno Clash has a very good aiming system meaning you can rotate between various different enemies and have the camera automatically face the location they are in. The majority of Zeno Clash's graphics are really top notch; something we should expect from a Source Engine game though. This game is six years old and still looks like a current generation game in my eyes. I played this on a 4K resolution and it looked absolutely stunning (for the most part). Where I ran into a weird graphic problem, was the tutorial. I am not sure whether it was a bug or glitch for me, but the resolution/texture quality/anti aliasing, was absurdly bad on all the tutorial scenes.  I really didn't know what was happening, I went from looking at a stunning 4k rendered world, to something which looks like a SNES has just produced. Like I said, this only happened for me on the tutorial levels, the rest of the game was absolutely fine. Zeno Clash has a good story; one that has a lot of olive branches into a few smaller stories, but focuses on the main story for the majority of the time. The game ends well and will leave you wanting to find out more about the world of Zenozoik (I just love the name of this place!).This game has three levels of difficulty; I played on normal and had a sufficiently challenging playthrough, there are no points which had me running against a brick wall for hours - I had to retry a couple of times. I can see the harder difficulty to be a real challenge though, since the handicap fights can get real hectic if you don't keep track on where all of your enemies are at ALL times - you will end up getting your head beat in from behind and you won't even realize. A full playthrough of Zeno Clash's story mode took me just about five hours; the rest of the time I spent in the challenge mode, which allows you to climb a tower and have your scores ranked every time you beat the final boss. In total I got about fourteen hours worth of gameplay out of it, so for £6,99, I am very happy with that outcome. Other than the strange graphical glitches I had on the tutorial modes; I did experience a few crashes. This came from when trying to use anything related to the Steam Overlay such as screenshots, or shift+tabbing to bring up your friends list whilst in game; this instantly crashed me to the desktop. The game also doesn't have a manual save function, so you are relying heavily on the auto save feature. Normally when I am playing a game which I have experienced crashes on, I try to save as often as I can, so when I found out I couldn't manually saved, it made me very cautious and was often on edge hoping for it not to crash, which somewhat spoiled the experience for me.  I also had a problem where the game would not count any of my achievements,  whether this is because of the issue with the Steam Overlay or not - I'm not sure. To sum up; I will recommend Zeno Clash as a very good PC game; it's standing the test of time very well, has some very nice graphics, a compelling story line and decent gameplay. If you don't experience any crashes or bugs, then you will have yourself a welcome addition to your Steam library in this game. If you can't really overlook the issues; then this may be one of the only times I say to try the console version out since that sounds like it is virtually bug free. Thankfully Steam does have a demo up for this game, so you can try it out first before purchasing - which is something I would highly recommend you do.  Tom's Score Card1) Stay away2) Only recommended when on sale3) Recommended4) Highly recommended5) This is a must playIf you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
xeno- prefix. from Ancient Greek ξένος (ksénos, “alien”) a. Having to do with foreigners, as in xenophilia, or more commonly, xenophobia. b. From a foreign place, as in xenolith.clash noun. onomatopoeic a. A skirmish, a hostile encounter. b. Opposition, contradiction, such as between differing or contending interests, views, purposes etc.In my imagination, the development of Xeno-- sorry, Zeno Clash -- started when folks at Ace Team got together, got high, and got onto the subject of ancient mythologies (Roman, Greek, Norse, etc.) and how weird they all were. I mean, if you want crazy characters and crazier stories, you need look no further than some of the gods and goddesses traipsing around back in the day. Athena, birthed fully formed out of the sweaty forehead of Zeus; Pan, the goat-god of wanton sex; Artemis, goddess of the hunt, who for some reason was depicted in various interpretations as being literally covered with breasts; Medusa, she of the stylish snake perm and stony gaze, being some kind of metaphor for psychosexual wackiness (I'm pretty sure we can blame Freud for that); Jeff, the God of Biscuits; and even some nutter who told people to eat some bread and drink some wine and pretend it was his flesh and his blood... I mean, ew, dude. I'm sure we have enough problems without adding cannibalism to it. So anyway, the developers were shooting the breeze about Gods and Golden Fleece and rivers of blood and whatever until one guy, as I imagine it, stood up and went, "Yeah... but like, what if... Dude! What if there were, like, aliens, right? And they were weird, like totally, heh, but then, like, THEY also had myths and♥♥♥♥♥♥ I mean... dude..."So that's where this game comes from, more or less. There is a distinct dreamlike quality inherent in the stories of myth, fantastical and larger than life, and that is the feeling you get as you find your way through the land of Zenozoik. It feels deliciously alien and new, in the visuals and in the story (neither of which go out of their way to make a lot of sense, but it's still easy enough to follow). You'll see and hear a lot of weird stuff, and sooner or later, you just go with the flow because it's weirdly seductive. Even running on the old Source engine, and looking a bit dated now in 2015, the art and design and imagination of the dev team comes through in nearly every area so that you will truly think you are in fact running around on an impossibly, impossibly alien world. Luckily, they do at least have one thing in common with us here on Earth: they really like punching the stuffing out of each other.If you've seen anything about Zeno Clash you already know the basics: it's a first-person brawler-shooter. Way more emphasis on the brawling than the shooting, thankfully. You, a fugitive on the run, have a modest set of fighting moves at your disposal, such as light and strong punches, blocks, dodges, counterattacks, grabs and throws. Unfortunately, so do your opponents for the most part, although they will also attack you at range if they get a chance. You get a small selection of weapons yourself, and they come in handy once in a while but the majority of your combat will be served in knuckle sandwiches. And they were never so tasty: combat feels fantastic in this game. It's fun, responsive and fast, with a good amount of variety (though there could be more), and it's super satisfying to land an uppercut on some chump and watch him go flying. I didn't really think I'd enjoy such a melee-focused FPS but after playing this I stand corrected, it's ridiculously fun. I even enjoyed the few bits where you are required to tote a rifle or another firearm, although I am glad those bits were few. They're not bad, really -- the rifle in particular sounds great, and it's amusing to plunk away at dudes with the double-fisted handguns -- but save for a couple spots you won't really get that much of a chance to use them because enemies will do their best to rush you if you're shooting at them, and none of the weapons are viable at close quarters.One thing you will notice right off the bat is the voice acting, and it is... hmm. How to describe it. Well, your first impression will probably be "Oh my god this is bad." And you wouldn't really be wrong, especially with regards to the main character. He is, let's say, from the same acting school as Christopher Walken and William Shatner, only he flunked out hard. His lines are awkwardly paced, and weirdly inexpressive; he speaks in a stilted, matter-of-fact tone. All of that might turn you off -- which is why I'm mentioning it -- but honestly, his weirdness actually fits the game very well. There is often dialogue that sounds so insane on paper, but because of the way he delivers his lines, it instead sounds believable and ordinary, which makes the bizarre setting of the game even more bizarre. All in all, it works for me. It may not work for you.It's not a very long game (ignore my obscenely long playtime), but it's a fully-formed, enjoyable, weird as all hell story that will have you doing at least one or two double-takes because you have probably never heard sentences like these in a game before. The fighting is hard and fast and so enjoyable, the world is filled with delicious weirdness for your eyes, and the trusty Source engine shines through even for a six year old game. I don't know about you, but it absolutely charmed the pants off me with how little Ace Team cared for making the "right" game, and made a fun, unique, and beautifully bizarre one instead.

Posted: January 18, 2015
												+ Combat system is incredibly simple and satisfying; everything connects and feels right, making this the game's greatest strength+ Character designs are creative and interesting; just the right mixture of weird and entertaining+ Strange weapon designs; very original in every respect (if you've seen the 1999 film ExistenZ, imagine the chicken bone gun, and populate an entire game-world with the same concept)+ Control scheme is efficient, and every button-press felt natural and satisfying+ Strange, yet appropriate soundtrack; did well to set the mood and keep you feeling mildly unsettled+ Atmospheric elements worked well with the environmental set-pieces to make for an absolutely bizarre world; I must say that this level of creativity, while unconventional, was a breath of fresh air+ Challenging, adaptive AI; enemies really keep you on your toes in the best possible way (save for a few, minor shortcomings - some of the bosses are also a bit too easy to cheese)- Terrible voice-acting- Stiff, clumsy animations- Frustrating and unnecessary lock-on system- Save for a (rather dull) Challenge Mode, and the ability to unlock cheat codes for the campaign, this title has virtually no replay value- Largely weak sound effects- Poorly explained, muddled plot with little character development and too many answers left out (topped off with a mediocre cliffhanger)LockeProposal's Big Day OutCommunity GroupCurator PageSerious Steam Reviews subReddit

content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												Truly a masterpiece. Fight your way to the truth of an unhinged world through mobsters, monsters, deranged beings and dark creatures.Zenozoik is a wonderful, vivid world, but this is no paradise. Forget the tales about the 'good savage', for this land is full of secrets and violence. Find out the reason of the brutal hunting you suffer from your own brothers, the secret crimes Ghat has come to know. In this first journey in Zenozoik, there'll be some revelations, but also questions that'll make you wish everything hidden to be brought into the open. The world ACE Team has created is really unique, and you'll always feel that there's much more to see... and to fight. Because Zeno Clash is above all, a brawling game, and it excels on it. The extraordinary plot backs an addictive and satisfying combat system, and luckyly the game includes modes beyond the main history which will sate your thirst for beating throwing you right into the action, in the increasingly harder stages of a tower which progressive destruction will delight you by its smart use of physics. Zeno Clash is an indispensable, which will remind you why some games deserve to be considered art; exalted visuals, surprising lore and relentless fights await you. Welcome to Zenozoik, brother.

												8/10Strong fantasy appeal.  The world and story is of new mythology.  Fighting system is challenging, fun, annoying, and very immersive.  For the most part the game is moderate difficulty from beginning to end.  Some of the fights can be easily beaten once you find a weakness in the A.I. or level design.  The game favors freaks who love originality.  The short length was perfect for the story.  Because it is a short game I would reccomend getting it on sale.  Overall a very enjoyable experience.  I have gained a number of concepts and ideas that will occupy my daydreams for the next month or so. I will be getting Zeno Clash 2 next time it is on sale.[If you are having problems with the fighting system then wait a few months and come back to it.  Start the game over and try again.  Worked for me.]

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
TL:DR? See ConclusionINTRODUCTION:Zeno Clash is a first-person melee fighting game developed by ACE Team using Valve's famous Source Engine and released on Steam back in 2009.The story begins with Ghat, the game's protagonist, waking up after being knocked out by an explosion which killed a creature known as Father-Mother who is the leader of a very powerful mafia like family in the small town of Halstedom. The protagonist Ghat is presumably one of Father-Mother's children who turned rogue and ran away from home and is now being pursued by his 'brothers and sisters' (enforcers of Father-Mother). Join him and his companion Deadra in a quest to discover the truth of about Ghat's past and trace back the series of events that led to the explosion.PROS:+ Excellent use of the Source Engine+ Good fisticuffs (melee) combat mechanic+ Surreal world and environment+ Complex but enjoyable story+ Interesting character, item and monster designs+ Item variety+ Good sound effects and voice acting+ The Devs were probably high during this game's production+ Challenging difficultiesCONS:- Extremely short (4-5 hours game time in my last playthrough)- Almost no replay value (except for the tower challenge mode)- Difficult learning curve- Story is a bit difficult to follow- Short linear levels (In my opinion, linear games are fine as long as the levels are lengthy and enjoyable)- No character progression (no armors, level ups or item upgrades)CONCLUSION:GOOD GAME. Zeno Clash sports a very unique art style that places you in a very surreal world with a strange geography and is populated by strange creatures all brought to life by the developer's clever use of Valve's Source Engine. The combat mechanics is fun albeit a little frustrating at times and hard to learn however, the items does give variety to the player's fighting style. The game should provide you with at least 4-5 hours of game time with its campaign with an added 'Tower Challenge' if the player wants to test his skills.I RECOMMEND this game mostly for the experience but the short game time could be an issue, still though, Zeno Clash is a fun game to play. I can't honestly cannot recommend it at full price (even if it is only $10 or your regional equivalent), so getting it on a sale is probably a better idea.--------------------------------------------------------- Like my Reviews? Follow my Curator's Page:http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6861651-Miyumi%27s-Review-Corner/

Some of the designs are awesome, funny and nice, others are just plain ugly and it doesn't always fit together. Posted: February 21, 2014
												Very strange, to be honest, I thought someone dosed me with something, I had to ask and confirm with other people that this game was real. The gameplay at its heart is a first person brawler, with a healthy mix up of shooting here and there. but the story, woa ho ho.... man. imagine a world that was generations deep with inbreeding, as well as cross breeding with chickens and pigs, and not the cute jrpg way, but more of a demented master blaster way. This is the world you're going to get into with this game.I did not like the melee combat at first, but the story kept me playing, and I ended up finding that the parry hit and run knee to the face smash tactics to be, well....... really good. and by the end of the game I found myself actually wanting to toss my guns down and put my fists up. It's short, but left me satisfied. I hope we see more of this twisted world.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												  Zeno Clash is a wierd game that tries to, and succeeds at, doing something that no other FPS has done.  The story is strange, the characters are mysterious, and the player is left continuously wondering what will happen next.  Unfortunately, the story is also not interesting. The game just throws disparate scenario after scenario at you presented as a series of events that happened before the beginning of the game, and it leaves it largely up to you to connect these events.  The characters are not expanded upon, the enemies are only briefly expounded on, and the main characters motivations are left entirely unclear.  I believe this was a choice made deliberately to add mystery to the story, but for me it only left me wanting for a clear reason to continue to my goal.  None of this would be a problem if the game was fun.  I don't need a reason to complete the game if I enjoy playing it.  Zeno Clash is unique in that it tries to blend melee and ranged combat in an FPS in a way I've never seen before.  The melee portion includes blocking, counter attacks, dodging, grabs, and other staples of good melee combat.  The mechanics of the game is what brings it down in this respect.  It would take a long time to describe exactly how frustrating it is to control the combat, but I frequently ended up performing the wrong defensive move which would result in my taking damage.  Furthermore, the counterattacks don't work.  Almost every time I tried to counter an enemy they would block or dodge my counterattack.  The ranged combat has similar problems.  Guns are not meant to be used exclusively.  You are supposed to pick up a weapon and shoot an enemy as many times as you can until they get close to you.  This part feels good.  Watching an enemy running towards you, it feels great to score those two big hits that send them flying on their back then pelting them with more shots until they start towards you again.  When they start getting closer though is when the frustration begins.  When an enemy gets close, you are meant to lock on to put away your weapon and begin melee.  However, running away from an enemy breaks your lock, so if you are trying to get away, the gun comes back out.  If you are hit with the gun out, it drops to the ground with whatever ammo it had, where enemies can pick it up and use it against you.  In short, again, the mechanincs of this game make it very frustrating to do what you want to do, and to fight multiple enemies.  In conclusion, I wanted to like this game.  I like wierd games, I like difficult games, and I like story-driven games.  I HATE frustrating games, however, and this falls squarely into that last category.  The mechanincs of combat don't work, the story was not holding my interest, and I felt no reason to complete the game.  In addition, I found a Zeno Clash process running in the background of my PC even though I hadn't played the game in days and the game itself was not running, so my hours played are inflated.  I should note I did not finish this game.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2015
												Zeno clash is probably one of the more memorable games I've played this year. Set in one of the most creative worlds I have ever witnessed, this game stands out as a real gem to me.+Well-developed melee fighting where you can lash together combos, strike quickly or strongly, or pick a median attack. Blocking, dodging, countering, finishing. Many great moves to help you deal with the situation at hand.+Ranged weapons that work fairly well from dual-wielded pistols, rifles, crossbows, or 'grenade launchers'. All very imaginatively designed in a way that they're nothing like you'd imagine based upon how I just described them. Unfortunately they make some fights a little too easy, but without them those same fights would have been a bit too hard.+It's challenging, but not unfair. Many games today are either too easy, or designed unfairly to promote difficulty. Zeno clash is almost the perfect median between the two.+The voice acting for the characters is simply splended. Every voice actor was given strange roles to fit, very specific roles, and they all nailed them with excellence. +Great and memorable characters. From the moral-less Ghat, to the kind and caring Deadra, to the mysterious Father-Mother and all of his-her sons and daughters you face throughout the game. To the also-mysterious Golem, and even to the many unique Corwid you face throughout the game. Oxameter and Gabel being the most memorable.+The story is confusing to begin with, but as you progress and learn more about what's happening it is fantastic. Absolutely great. Unfortunately it ends in a bit of a cliff hanger but that's fine! We have a sequel available to us! +The world is simply stunning. The setting is so unique and refreshing, I just want to experience more and more of it. Give me more!+The music fits the game so well! Matching every moment almost perfectly! Well-arranged tracks as well.+A challenge mode to keep you entertained after you beat the main story, which is well needed since....-I finished the game in a little over 3 hours. And the challenge mode will keep you busy for about one extra hour, which is nice.I give this game a solid 9/10. How short it is is what holds it back from its full potential, but this is a game no one should miss. Definitely pick this one up as soon as possible!

content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												I'm trying to think of the best way to advise somebody just now picking this game up, whether by random choice or under pressure from their friends. Of course, the latter will probably result in disappointment. Don't let the buzzwords (quirky, awkward, weird, crazy) fool you. The game is (though I loath to use this term) "quirky," to be sure, the story and voice work have an awkward, disjointed feel, as does the game's art style. Trust me when I say this is all intentional on the part of the devs, and isn't just a pointless dive at becoming the strangest thing since Vangers.If you have ever been told this game is "deep," it's because of the revelations of the sequel, Zeno Clash 2. Anyone suggesting you play the first part of a series because of how much THEY enjoyed the revelations of the second part is like someone watching Return of the King, going bananas over the charge of the Rohirim and suggesting you pick up the extended edition of Fellowship when you have no experience with LOTR whatsoever. You will not enjoy it. PLAY THIS GAME WITHOUT ANY EXPECTATIONS WHATSOEVER. Ignore the exaltations of your peers.As for how "quirky" and "awkward" this game is, like I said, it's intentional. There's a suitable comparison in the 1984 movie Scanners. The protagonist is a man who has been mute his entire life, and suddenly regains the power of speech. It's not very well elaborated upon in the film, but his social skills and speech patterns are completely out of whack because of this: he has to develope these skills almost from the ground up. The people who inhabit the world of Zeno Clash have a similar problem, which is elaborated upon in the sequel; again, perhaps explaining why people think this game is so "deep."Gameplay is fairly simple and quite challenging. First person hand-to-hand is a very peculiar form of gameplay, particularly when it's as complicated as it is in both Zeno Clash 1 and 2. Though there is a limited variety of enemies, they all have unique fighting styles which you will have to adapt to in order to succeed. Enemies will fake you out, surprise you with the reach of their attacks, suddenly overwhelm you with a flurry of blows; to this day, whenever I pick up Zeno Clash I'm regularly intimidated and surprised by the combat, in spite of having played through the game multiple times. It's no surprise that some players are frustrated by how unpredictable it is and even reject the game entirely, dismissing it as quirky nonsense. Trust me, just have patience and work on your timing. Pick some good battle music and play the tower challenges. You'll probably find it as enjoyable and satisfying as I do.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												Zeno Clash is a very strange game with a great atmosphere. It's hard to describe how the game presents itself; you'll have to see it to understand it. Because of its modest price tag, this is definitely worth checking out for everyone who appreciates an action packed and strange experience or someone who is looking for something original. It's only a shame it's such a short experience.You'll either love it or hate it. If you can let the bizarre world and characters entice you, you will get your money's worth. Its flawed gameplay will annoy most people though. If you're open-minded, you might appreciate this unique experience.Zeno Clash is a marvel, channeling yesterday’s hardcore brawlers whilst maintaining modern sensibilities.Zeno Clash demonstrates why often the most Bizarre projects can only be developed by independent companies. No “major” could ever do something like this, and that’s because we are talking about one of the most suggestive and atypical titles of recent times.Despite the initial weirdness and a few flaws, Zeno Clash is a unique take on first-person fighting that anyone with an open mind will likely enjoy.Overall 7/10.

Posted: November 3, 2012
												If there ever was an award for weirdest world, Zeno Clash would be a top contender. The game starts with you killing your Father-Mother(Which is a single entity) under suspicious circumstances and it doesn't slow down from there as you progress both further away, running from your brothers and sisters, and back to the start, through flashbacks explaining how you came to kill your Father-Mother. At no point does Zeno Clash attempt to make excuses for it's insane universe, no explanation is given for anything that does not fit within the games context, things simply are.Some will love this and some will hate it but either way you can't help but admire the writers for making such an uncompromising world that gives you one WTF? moment after the other with barely a second to catch your breath.The gameplay is simplistic repetitive beat-em-up not worth mentioning but the game should be played, if only to experience the madding world of Zeno Clash, whose like you won't find anywhere else.

Posted: April 9
												Zeno Clash is truly a masterpiece. It’s an uncommonly strange and bizarre first-person beat ‘em up game set in a punk fantasy world. This game has a deep and compelling story. It's filled with very interesting and surreal characters and environments, which make this game an unforgettable experience.

number of helpful: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2016
												It's safe to say that Zeno Clash wouldn't work as a big budget game from an established studio; it's far too different from convention, which would mean it's far too risky a project for them. But it's a perfect example of how some of the best and most original ideas are coming out of independent teams that have talent and passion and can take risk because they're not gambling with tens of millions of dollars. Zeno Clash sticks with you long after you play it, and that's a compliment many games aspire to have associated with them.

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												What the heck is Zeno Clash?Zeno clash is a first person bang em up type game where the player can punch or kick the crap out of his opponents. Seems like simple fun arcade stuff right? Sort of is, but there are added features to the game (beside the campaign) that make it significant. The storyline is a good one to say the least. There is a guy who trains you in the game and by the time he's done training you, he simply kills himself. This game is whacky, weird, and odd, but how it all comes together within the world is awesome. When people speak about creative games, this one definitely takes the cake with it's outrageous characters. Besides the game play, the characters alone will make you double take. They are given personalities with extreme oddity that simply makes it appealing. I fought a boss who jumped on top of a bunch of dinosaurs while trying to kill me for pete's sake. I really like the fighting engine and the added features of being able to pick up guns, crossbows, and other sort of crazy weaponry like blunt objects that send opponents flying. When you fight, it actually feels like you're making contact with the opponent. The feedback in the punches was done phenomenally. Should you buy it? On sale I would say unless you REALLY like these types of games.For future Zeno Clash games I would recommend multiplayer, and maybe even dare to try to incorporate local co-op. To add to the fighting, perhaps add kicks or even allow for players to hold down the mouse button, then use the mouse to swing to determine the type of swing. Don't make it to the point where people start snapping their mouse cord, but something decently close enough.RATING : 8.2/10get's an extra .2 for being a breakaway new type of genre.Gameplay B+ Story / Campaign A- Visuals / User Interface B Sounds / Music B Replay-ability B- Overall  B

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												A short, but action packed journey in a unique world.You are on the run, hunted by your own family for the murder of your own father - or better - Father-Mother, aided only by the young woman by your side.The story is split in two parallel storylines: your present and your past, which will unfold via flashbacks, as you narrate your past and motives to your only remaining friend, and will take you to the very end of the world, before you decide to return home to settle your past once and for all.Gameplay-wise, the combat in this game is praised as one of the best melee combat experiences in gaming, and while I don't fully agree, I certainly see how it may be so for many people.You will find an immersive first person combat system, where every punch and every block counts, and mostly, FEELS right.In the end, it is a short story of ideals and revelations that may even manage to make you think of society as we see it.Hard to recommend to everyone, although it is so short (I completed it in 5h and I'm sure it can be completed in a little less) that even those who simply seek an alternative adventure won't be too weighed down. I do recommend it, however, to first person brawlers' fans, you will be given every tool to test your fighting skills.In short: short, first person brawler with excellent, fleshed out combat and a story with a morale set in a bizarre world.

												Pros-Interesting fighting style.-Rebindable keys.-Default field of view is 90° and can be modified via "fov_desired #".-Supports subtitles.Cons-Poor voice acting.-Bad character animations.-Sometimes your kicks and punches will not register and will go through your enemy.-Combination keys, example: The key for  "Block/Throw Weapon" is "SPACE", why can't can't they separate each action to each individual key?-Some events are scripted, such as some enemies are not meant to die.-Game is really shortOther info-The game is very linear.-The game itself is very strange.-I find the game to be very repetitive.-Large address aware is not supported.-32-bit executable.PCGamingWiki Page: http://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Zeno_Clash

												Would you like a game that's really simple yet solid, like the beat'em ups from the days of yore (but in first person view)? What about an art style that looks like the lovechild of Roger Dean and David Cronenberg on acid? A soundtrack with a wild sense of urgency? Do you want to feel like Kenshiro from Hokuto no Ken, punching people into the air, while the story discreetly discusses  Sartrean Existentialism and Hobbesian societal notions? Do you want to shoot multibreasted rat people with a fishgun? What about birdmen? Then this game is for you!!!!!

content:
Posted: March 3, 2016
												I mainly knew about ACE team because of the incredibly impressive Batman Doom, but I was surprised they were a commercial studio. I was definitely not disappointed in their first commercial effort. Simple, effective gameplay and visuals that feel straight out of Heavy Metal. First person brawlers need a much bigger presence. I've played an hour and a half but I'm halfway through the game. The simplicity makes up for the length though, and it feels like it can offer more replay in return. Don't bother complaining about it, you probably have more games in your Steam account than you can finish in your lifetime anyways. Be thankful you're not getting a 50 hour timesink that you'll put off playing forever because of the daunting length.

												I'm going to give the controversial opinion and say that I didn't really enjoy this game.The first person combat is amazing, yes. I love the way that the first person fighting mechanics feel. But the story just could not hold my interest.The world you are put in is such an interesting and creative one, yet the plot is so jointed and disconnected that I never felt like I got to know the world very well. The story and plot was just too confusing for me to understand. Many aspects just felt unexplained, and the game ends on a sequel hook cliffhanger.Is the game worth trying? Sure. But personally? I felt the confusing story made the game drag on far too long.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												Maybe you watched The Dark Crystal and thought, "Man, I sure would like to beat the $&!? out of everyone and everything in this world!" This is pretty close. It's like, "The Dark Crystal... Meth".First person boxing and melee that mostly works with some ranged weapons thrown in. An older source engine game, the effects (lighting, atmosphere, reflections) look nice but not amazing. The art design itself is wildly creative and a highlight of the experience. The gameplay is not perfect, sometimes it can be frustrating because of the targeting mechanic (you lock on an opponent then need to unlock to regroup effectively), but it was actually quite satisfying overall. Some good brawls and decent variety, and when you need a weapon, it'll be there.The story is the stuff of dark fairy tales and myth. It is pretty weird and told with flashbacks that roll into the present. But it makes sense, in a dreamy sort of way. The voice acting is solid. Just don't expect a lot of character depth or the option to interact with anyone in any way besides pummeling the holy $&!? out of them. Not a very long game, Zeno Clash has a challenge ladder if you wanna fight some more.  I'd actually say it was a good length because it didn't get boring. The hand to hand combat combined with the great weird visuals makes this a pretty good buy for $10, or a great buy for .99 cents. Looking forward to Zeno Clash 2 :)

content:
Posted: July 13, 2016
												- This review isn't written by a native speaker, thank you for your understanding -- If you haven't found this review helpful or if you have found a mistake please leave a comment below -- Note : I got this game in a bundle on Bundlestars, the game alone should be around $0.30 -Rating Must PlayFamily rating  between Teen and Mature- Key features below ---- Review after -----------------------------------------------Play time needed (perfect) about 16 hoursGaming level CasualAchievements level CasualGame style First Person Shooter, Fighting, Beat Them AllGame modes Story mode, Challenge modeGraphics Good. (first release was on 2009)Story Good!Playthrough OneVoice GoodMusic Good.Controls Keyboard and mouse. Controller?Tutorial Yes!Backtracking/Unmissable Backtrackable. One missable. Check the (#) point at the end.Glitches / bugs At least one. Check the (*) point at the end.Worth price It can deserve its full price if you really love the game. I suggest to get it discounted though.- Review below ----------------------------------------------------------------------Zeno Clash is a unique game in its genre : a first person fighter - beat-them-all set in a tribal punk fantasy world. You play as Ghat all along his journey exiled from his tribe through the end of the world. Helped by his sister he will face many opponents and dangers to survive along his exile : that will includes many brothers and sisters of his own Father-Mother (an hermaphrodite creature) as well as a hired head-hunter, the Corwid of the Free's tribe and many critters.But Ghat isn't weak at all, quite the contrary, he is really strong despite his thin shape. He also learned how-to fight with Metamoq the chief of Corwid of the Free. So he knows how to fight using his fists or melee or gun weapons.The game features levels, meaning that there is no at lot to explore but there are many brawls and fights to come through. Despite that, there are many new environments and concepts to make the game quite interesting. Also each level are independent meaning that weapons you had at the end of a level won't be transferred to the next level. (Unless the bombs are but I'm not sure) So as you understood each level as its own weapons, enemies and fruits in specific places. The game consists in exploring (a little) and fighting/brawling waves of foes and bosses. The HUD is very simple : you got your own portrait with your health and stamina bars. Every time you run or prepare a strong attack you use stamina which will be restored slowly. And don't be afraid for your health bar running low, there are always some fruits that give you some health back as well as some checkpoint that restore you whole health ! The HUD show you also the remaining bombs you got.Adding to the story mode there is also a challenge mode. Challenges take place in a tower, split in two area : the top and the bottom. If you are going in the top you are going to fight many foes on each level using the given weapons or not (you can brawl instead most of the time) to reach the top level which include the story boss as well as many foes at the same time ! If you are going at the bottom, you'll need to fight foes and make you way below by jumping platform by platform using bombs if needed to break a whole platform to make a hole. But don't forget to take care of every foe cause you won't go deeper until you dealt with all of them. So you can push them all in the pit below but you'll need to face all the survivors at the end. Also when you'll go deeper you'll encounter golden enemies which are more powerful and tougher. Each level can be played independently so it's not a real survival game. At the end of each challenge you'll be in the leaderboard with the time you've made and the remaining health. So you can compete with your friends on steam.That's not all : you have also 70 Zeno Clash characters and foes patterns for Garry's Mod.I would really recommend this game !(*): A very uncommon issue happened to me in the Corvid of the Free forest : after I've beat up every foe the game keep playing without occurring the next wave. But after waiting / moving several minutes the next wave appeared.(#): I would say almost every achievement can be backtracked and several of them are kept while making another playthrough or replaying some levels. Only one "difficult" achievement requires you to play the whole story from the beginning to the end using weapons when you really need to. There are a lot of information on steam or elsewhere that explains when you need to use weapons or not. If you used one by mistake you can still kill yourself and try the current level but if you forgot to this playthrough will not count.

number of helpful: 11 of 18 people (61%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												First person games with good melee combat are sadly rare.  Too often it basically consists of flailing your arms with no force feedback until the enemy falls over (see Elder Scrolls).  Which is a a shame, because when these types of games do show up, they tend to be pretty awesome.As you can guess, Zeno Clash has good melee combat.  It's fairly simple, but it feels good.  You can dodge and block, punch and throw to your heart's content.  My only real complaint about the combat is that at times it feels a little barebones, especially because the game doesn't force you into most advanced techniques.  I rarely dodged or blocked in my playthrough (although I have yet to do the tower challenges).The melee segments are broken up by time with various other weapons, and a few boss battles.  I often found myself wishing I could go back to the melee combat (especially during the repetitive fights with heavy enemies), but even these segments were mildly enjoyable at worst and fun at best.The game also has a pretty good story.  It's simple and short, but it's supported by a wonderfully strange world, and it's fairly engaging.  It ends poorly though, with barely any sense of conclusion.  The game ends up feeling like a prologue for the sequel.All in all it's a very solid game.  Good melee combat, great world, fun variety of segments.  It's definitely not perfect: It's very short, and it's basically a series of scenes with fades between so it feels at times disjointed and restricting, but it's an enjoyable game, and worth playing if you like unique games or just want to beat up a bunch of weird creatures.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 31, 2013
												absurdism is difficult. that which is otherworldly, that which is abstract understanding, can only stem from relations of relations of corrupted understandings. people gravitate toward things far removed from understanding. people talk and caw about games having disparate worlds, but zeno clash is true. zeno clash features a world so far removed from anything in fiction or in living. its an absolute triumph of visual direction. zeno clash is a textbook on the deranged. with all of my praise though, it does remind one distinctly of oddworld. however, zeno clash’s world is much more lively - less barren to say - and there are many humans. though there are many other creatures as well.whatever zeno clash ended up looking like, the base idea is something I would sell myself off for. I am incredibly glad this game exists. beat ‘em ups are eternal for me. what rings incredibly true for zeno clash is how traditional it is. you fight with two kinds of punches, light and heavy. a light punch can strike up to three times and can be comboed into a strong. strong punches are kind of like a wind up punch; space yourself away from your target and dash in with your fist. both are incredibly satisfying thanks to impeccable animation and hit detection. if an enemy becomes dazed, they can be thrown. and that’s basically it. the basic tendency calls back the roots of the beat ‘em up genre, a very comfortable thing for me, and a very different trace of influence for a modern game. especially considering the direction beat ‘em ups have taken with devil may cry, ninja gaiden, and god of war - although those are fantastic titles - it’s nice to see a game toning things back. except, I’d probably enjoy a hyper-complex combat system more, in all honesty.if zeno clashed revolved around limited arena battles punching the trash out of fugly foes, and in saying that it does anyway, then it’d be a fantastic game that anyone looking for new ideas in their vidcons should play. it wouldn’t raise any intellectual hell, but exist as something more primal than serious sam, with an even goofier atmosphere. the boxing arenas are still totally worth it. but what was a successful formula gets bogged down by forced variance. ace team wasn’t content with the gold they struck - or maybe the gold was struck from altering their original first person shooter formula? either way, there are guns in the game. shoehorned guns. guns that are not fun to shoot or use. if they were options to use in the battle royals then they would be tarnishing, but forgivable. they are not. the gunplay is forced numerous times. thankfully they are not long, yet the damage is still felt. it’s not like anything is broken with the guns - it’s just they’re incredibly mediocre compared to your fists. the endworld is an exception to that with interesting and fun ranged combat. though pacing of using a magic wand leaves some to be desired and the enemies you fight are nothing more than zombies, it’s still darkly enchanting.ranged weapons present one problem and melee weapons present another. melee weapons have a light swing and a heavy swing, much like your hands. once again, they function like they always have in the genre. they’re usually satisfying to use and offer a break from cracking skulls with your knuckles all day. the problem isn’t in the melee weapons, but when you’re given them. not too often can you use them against normal facepunchers. heavyweight enemies can only be damaged and toppled by heavy weapons and only the charge attack really does any damage. this leads to very mediocre and unsatisfying fights. there are no gambits allowed, no subcombos to pull off, no variety to speak of. you distance yourself, wind up attack, strafe, bash, retreat, repeat. and zeno clash will just throw these fatties at you as the game progresses. they’ll be one with small guys, one coming right after another, and at one point in the game two at a time. the two at a time encounter is pretty damn cool honestly. still, they are static and unfun encounters, and drag down what should be the pinnacle of the game.if zeno clash had a more organic presentation it would be legendary. if you traversed large and odd levels, fisting waves of enemies, it would have ascended. even if it had rather linear levels with stop and fight sequences, it still would have delivered a wholly amazing game. instead you’re more often that not pitted in smallish arenas to fight your rounds. there are more traditional fps orientated levels to be found, but in those you do not punch, which is all the more confusing. levels are relegated to being plot excerpts filled with gameplay, instead of having the plot compliment the gameplay. its pacing is haphazard and disappointing. it wants to have this grand adventure and yet its levels are arcade in nature. not like double dragon arcade, but dig-dug. they’re just rounds. that feeling is even more horribly accented in the second half when you repeat most of the places you already walked through on your return trip home, just with harder enemies.sheer repetition is zeno clash’s greatest flaw. guns are no different from eachother besides how many bullets sit in the chamber. melee weapons offer no variation aside from different looking skins. both guns and weapons have wonderful models, but that’s not the kind of variation I’m vying for. there are many different and awesome looking enemies. those many different awesome looking enemies will be fought two to even three times each. their names are the same, I guess they are the same people, but when you fight the same enemies in the same level as a few hours before it feels really freaking lazy. with the two bounty hunter confrontations, both very great despite relying on poor gunplay, it’s more than obvious that ace team really wanted variation in their game. so the design choices in the meat of their game sit in ugly defiance to their vision. a real frustrating execution overall.writing is stilted. purposefully, the characters need to assume their roles as midsavages. there is a mighty depth and conviction to the script. made up words and made up accents. though, the voice acting does not match the quality of writing, and is rather poor. the story itself, framed as a mystery, compliments the game’s piecemeal length. when it’s all said and done though the plot is a bit flat. it’s not really about what ghat did so much as ghat dealing with why he did it. with the characters being in a generally unrelatable state of mind, the implications aren’t so interesting to learn about. what’s great about the script is the weird things, the corwids, father-mother’s society, the endworld, golem’s crypticness. these things really draw you in. it succeds in vision and skill of writing even if it does not have the running time to tell a deep story.zeno clash is an addled burst of fraught strangeness smoothed with brand new gameplay. its short length makes it very easy to recommend, but it also is its greatest limiter with unrealized ideas all over the place. zeno clash is a small game and isn’t content with it. because of that, I’m not exactly content with it either.

delivered a wholly amazing game. instead you’re more often that not pitted in smallish arenas to fight your rounds. there are more traditional fps orientated levels to be found, but in those you do not punch, which is all the more confusing. levels are relegated to being plot excerpts filled with gameplay, instead of having the plot compliment the gameplay. its pacing is haphazard and disappointing. it wants to have this grand adventure and yet its levels are arcade in nature. not like double dragon arcade, but dig-dug. they’re just rounds. that feeling is even more horribly accented in the second half when you repeat most of the places you already walked through on your return trip home, just with harder enemies.sheer repetition is zeno clash’s greatest flaw. guns are no different from eachother besides how many bullets sit in the chamber. melee weapons offer no variation aside from different looking skins. both guns and weapons have wonderful models, but that’s not the kind of variation I’m vying for. there are many different and awesome looking enemies. those many different awesome looking enemies will be fought two to even three times each. their names are the same, I guess they are the same people, but when you fight the same enemies in the same level as a few hours before it feels really freaking lazy. with the two bounty hunter confrontations, both very great despite relying on poor gunplay, it’s more than obvious that ace team really wanted variation in their game. so the design choices in the meat of their game sit in ugly defiance to their vision. a real frustrating execution overall.writing is stilted. purposefully, the characters need to assume their roles as midsavages. there is a mighty depth and conviction to the script. made up words and made up accents. though, the voice acting does not match the quality of writing, and is rather poor. the story itself, framed as a mystery, compliments the game’s piecemeal length. when it’s all said and done though the plot is a bit flat. it’s not really about what ghat did so much as ghat dealing with why he did it. with the characters being in a generally unrelatable state of mind, the implications aren’t so interesting to learn about. what’s great about the script is the weird things, the corwids, father-mother’s society, the endworld, golem’s crypticness. these things really draw you in. it succeds in vision and skill of writing even if it does not have the running time to tell a deep story.zeno clash is an addled burst of fraught strangeness smoothed with brand new gameplay. its short length makes it very easy to recommend, but it also is its greatest limiter with unrealized ideas all over the place. zeno clash is a small game and isn’t content with it. because of that, I’m not exactly content with it either.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2012
												'Zeno Clash' is a debut game by ACE Team, who are the developers who recently released 'Rock of Ages'.This is an impressive title. Extraordinarily impressive. An FPS focusing mostly on brawling and few weapon mechanics, the gameplay is not only innovative, but stunningly creative and chocked full of potential. The imagination used to create this game is off the charts: it's a cornucopia of color and design. ACE has left no stone unturned when  creating an entirely new world. Not only do they focus on the visuals of the planet but also the unique culture, technology, wildlife, language and the natives that inhabit this strange new land. When it comes to being engulfed in a whole new reality, I've seen few games do it as seamlessly as 'Zeno Clash'.While the gameplay is unvaried and by no means perfect, this reasonably short foray leaves you wanting MORE. For 'Zeno Clash', this is a good thing. This is one game that will have you chomping at the bit for a sequel.

												It is truly dificult to put this game into words. I will say this now: If you like strange games, this may be a big hit for you. The playstyle was rather interesting with a first-person fist fighting game mingles with shooting mechanics as well. It has a decent enough story, considering how short it is, but it could do a bit better. The art is really the best part of this game, it is extremely unique with a tribal-apocalypse thing going. content:
Posted: October 10, 2016
												TLDRPro's-Good story-Neat characters-Good combat mechanicsCon's-Real Short-No replay value-Older graphics (not really a con)Well for starters it holds up pretty well for a 2009 game. Graphics and audio settings are outdated. But it still looks pretty good. I beat the game in about 3 hours (without encountering any glitches) and then played some of the challenges.The game takes place in a really strange world filled with all sorts of creatures and characters and not a lot of backstory. The campaign flip-flops with a normal mission and then a flashback mission as you figure out things and the story is told.The gameplay is a solid mix of hand-to-hand combat with some ranged weapons and larger enemies/special fights. It got slightly boring and repetitive because you fight the same characters over and over throughout the campaign. BUT the story is interesting enough for me to enjoy the slightly repetitive fighting. After the campaign there isnt much replay value other than a few easter eggs and achievments. However there are  combat challenges that offer some extra content. I didn't finish all of them but someone that absolutely loves the game would.All around its a solid game, i'm not sure i'd pay more than $5 for it. A great outcome from such a small studio7/10

content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
												Gameplay:You can normal punch, strong punch, block and dodge. You can also do some advanced techniques like a super strong punch, a rushed elbow hit, and if you block then press your normal punch or strong punch button you can land a devastating quick kick. It's pretty simple. There are also weapons that have a small "magazine" (the best gun I found had 3 shots before I had to reload). You mostly walk in a straight line.  It is kind of dreamlike because even though it is linear many of the things from point A to B are cut out. For example in one part you are in the forest and then 5 minutes later (after a fight) you are in the coast. The gameplay is simple but fun.Story:Without giving too much away: Ghat murders Father-Mother (the name implies everything). He is on the run and his girlfriend (Deadra) tags along cause I don’t know. You get many flashbacks that tell more of the story and you try to piece it together. He refuses to tell his girlfriend Father-Mother's secret (why he killed it). This game is kind of weird. See a couple of the screenshots and you will see what I mean. The world looks twisted and colorful as do the characters. People are weird and some talk in riddles. You definitely will be laughing at some points in the game.Definitely get it. The story mode is short but you also get a challenge mode. I believe there is an SDK for this game but I haven’t come across any mods.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
												Zeno Clash is a First Person "Brawler" by Chilean developer ACE Team. Made in the Source Engine, Zeno Clash is nothing but oozing in creativity. From the zany monster design to the intriguing weapons, the game creates an original setting the likes of which are not often seen amongst games these days. Although I mentioned weapons earlier, the meat of the games combat comes from the brawling segments. Through the usage of a stamina bar and several combos and counters, Zeno Clash attempts to be a first person fist-fighting game. In this it succeeds, though it will take some time to get used to the combat. It draws certain parallels to Dark Souls almost: both games have heavy and light attacks, blocking, and parrying. The games does so many things right such as introducing all fights with cool illustrations of the foes and breaking up the gameplay with various weapons, boss fights and changes of locale, that it doesn't fall hard to forgive it for its biggest flaw, namely voice acting. It being an Indie game and all it's not hard to understand why the voice acting might be less than stellar, but its a minor point that shouldn't impede anyone's enjoyment of the game. Zeno Clash is, among other things a first person brawler done right with one of the best fantasy settings in modern games.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												A first-person beat'em up game at it's finest! The world of Zeno Clash is very bizarre and weird which make exploring even more fun :D The main focus of the combat system are the melee fights.  It is pretty basic and not very complicated to master the melee system. You can punch, kick, throw, block, evade and deflect attacks. Combine those possibilities with the physics engine turns to be a LOT of fun!The weapons are very easy to use. Most of them have unlimited ammo but need to be reloaded properly. If you want to put your weapon away for a melee fight, you just need to "lock on" to an enemy.The levels are pretty small but it works for this title. The only thing I didn't like it so far would be the skybox. It was pretty empty most of the time. The story is quite nice and makes you want to buy the sequel... KAK!

content:
Posted: July 19, 2012
												This is a first person melee brawler, which is quite a new take on the genre. The world is imaginatively designed and the music, while not particularly special is a nice mix of tribal music.Its a short and linear adventure at around 6 hours. Gameplay is a hit and miss. When the punches connect, they feel satisfying. However, it is frustrating when hit detection goes wonky. There is also a lock-on mechanic, while useful in theory, is a hassle when you need to get away from enemies. While there are also guns, they have too little ammo and load much too slowly to be effective in combat. The story is simple, but the way its presented is confusing and the characters aren't very memorable. The female sidekick you have doesn't help much at all in combat and would have been much better if she can be used as a co-op partner.Overall Rating: 6.5 / 10Not worth to buy full price, but worth a look if on sale. This is an unpolished gem and is a good first effort from this indie studio.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2016
												I got this game in a bundle awhile back and just recently got around to playing it.This is a first person fighting game with a unique art style. Another reviewer referred to it as "Stonepunk", and I feel that is an appropriate description.The first part of the game was interesting with the blend of first person fighting and gunplay, but by the end of the game I was more than ready to be done with it. The story and characters are mediocre at best, and the game is quite short. The combat, which starts out relatively fun, degenerates into a repetitive slugfest with you constantly getting overwhelmed by more enemies than you can keep track of (including snipers) and it simply ends up being not fun by the end.On top of that, the combat controls were glitchy and didn't always register, and there's some major issues with enemies being invincible during most animations and your character getting stuck in a corner and taking a ton of damage. The icing on the cake is the baffling control decision to have the block/dodge key also throw your weapon, which makes fights with certain types of enemies far more difficult/annoying than they should be since the only way to harm them is with a melee weapon, but they almost always block your attacks if you're in front of them. You basically have to sprint in a circle around them (and they still hit you half the time from angles you wouldn't expect, and do a ton of damage) when you should be able to dodge and counterattack (they can do it to you, why can't you return the favor?).Overall, when this game works, it's a satisfying first person brawler, but when it doesn't it is one of the most frustrating and annoying games I've played in awhile. While not a completely terrible game, it has enough issues and little enough content (you fight against the same dozen or so characters over and over again in the course of the game) that I can't really recommend it unless you got it for next to nothing in a bundle like I did.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												This is a very unique expierience that stands out from most games for various reasons that i will go into. i say that this game, atleast from me, gets a 9/10. why? let's find out.Visuals 10/10: this game's design is outlandish and surreal in almost every nook and cranny, but my oh my is it beautiful to look at. even though it does follow an invisible wall system, it feels as though you can just walk out and explore the world of zenoik. and that's just talking about it's scenery, it's characters are just as strange but fun to look at as their environment. from the corwids to the northern gate gang, there is a vibrant and bizarre variety of characters to see. and granted even though this game is considerably older than most next gen titles, it is very impressive for it's time.Gameplay 9/10: the concept of not relying on guns or swords but entirely on your fists sounds like anybody's childhood dream. and by god is it satisfying to punch somebody's face in in this game,and this right here is what makes this game so refreshing from the other titles. and it's great to feel that sense of impact when you hit someone or throw them into another fighter, through the majority of the game you'll have to rely on that. and even though there are weapons, they are all balanced to a degree in which you should only really use them if you absolutley have to. for example the club, it causes considerable damage to fighters but will break upon constant use. the cons about this though is the fact that i wish there were more combinations and ways to inflict damage than there already are. for example maybe adding in a right punch left punch system that would allow and demand for combo moves. but overall, it is a solid gameplay system.Story 7.5/10: this is where zeno clash starts to show some pretty bad flaws, it's story is fantastic and it's thought provoking. but it's really hard to follow sometimes and it cause alot of confusion with how fast things go by, especially the flashbacks, in which ghat explains why did what he did. but they seem to go by at the speed of sound sometimes expecting it's audience to keep up. however! it's voice acting and characterization is what saves it, you will remember who is who with their unique design and backgrounds and they will serve as reminders for later on if you happen to have forgotten what has happened. overall, it's an amazing storyline hindered by minor plotholes and really fast pacing.Concept 10/10: probably one of the most crisp and unique designs i've seen to date. for stonepunk is not a genre you hear all too often due to it not sounding all that appealing or fun. but it is indeed a sight to behold, and what i love most about it is it's independence in character design, you could add a rock man wearing bones around him and he'd fit in just fine. and it's design may turn others away for fearful reasons even, for some of the characters do look very bizarre and for some quite hideous or terrifying. but if your tired of seeing copy and paste soldiers or sexy chicks with no other purpose than being attractive. than this is a design worth looking into.Replayability 9/10: this is an absolute joy to play, whether your looking for overly fun gameplay or delicous eyecandy this is worth the price it has. for there are many possibilities for how you can go about fights in the second playthrough, for example you may have been beaten by jsaj over a million times due to you just starting the game but be able to be an equal or better fighter than he is on the second try due to knowing how to play better. as for the story, you can play it again and have a more clear understanding of things, but as for all story based games you will already know what will happen. so nothing will suprise you too much. Overall: this is a diamond in the rough for video game standards, with a concept so bold that it could've really sunk all the way down to rock bottom. but it succeeds in what it tries to accomplish, bare knuckle fightin'. it almost makes me wish that there were more first person punchers out there with how well this turned out. and even though it feels as though it sacrifices a good story for better gameplay, i don't think many will complain if they just want to have fun. but in all honesty, this is a must have in my opinion for those who want to see something new and done well on their plate.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												In Zeno Clash, you play as Ghat who is part of a 'family' by this strange creature known as Father-Mother. During the beginning of the game, things won't be very clear except that the supposed brothers and sisters that are a part of this family accuse you of killing Father-Mother. More is revealed as you progress in the game and you eventually find out the truth. Personally, I won't go into further details about the story to avoid spoilers.The gameplay is very unique in such a way that you don't often see this genre...This game plays in a first person perspective but your use of combat isn't through weapons (there is ranged weapons in the game, but you won't always be using them) instead, you use your fists to beat the ever living crap out of whoever stands in your way. You can lock on to your enemies and switch between which can be handy for quickly knowing when to defend or attack. At some areas of the game, your fists alone won't be reliable enough to hurt some enemies as some of them can vary from big enemies who charge at you and can knock you over resulting in some nasty damage or you have creatures that spit crap at you. So what do you do when it comes down to that? You use weapons! You can pick up some unique looking weapons that help from dual welded bone like pistols to a crossbow that fires skulls that explode upon impact with your enemies or you can have a bone sledgehammer that can deal massive damage to your enemies as you charge your swing.The level design is incredibly trippy but that's likely what the developers were going for as the world of Zeno Clash is incredibly unreal and is full of plenty of strange yet pretty scenary.Zeno Clash also has a unique tower mode which you unlock levels of as you progress through the main story. In the tower mode, you are inside a tower killing every enemy in the room to progress higher into the tower and you also also put against a time which shows how long you take. The timer isn't all too important as its just to put you against your friends to see who's faster at the level. As you progress, you'll meet all the different enemies you have met throughout the main game and in some rooms, you will have weapons that you can use or disarm from your enemies. But in the later levels there will also be room hazards that can be useful for killing your enemies in one fell swoop but be careful! As if you aren't, you can also be killed quickly.All in all, Zeno Clash is a incredibly fun game where you beat the crap out of people and I recommend checking it out if you're looking to punch in some faces! Plus, if you buy it and own Garry's Mod, you'll get all the models from the game!

content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
												Zeno Clash is a very interesting First Person Brawler, in which you play as Ghat, one of the many children of the strange FatherMother, who, after killing FatherMother, is chased out of town by his own brothers and sisters. The game's story starts right after FatherMother's murder, but there's also flashback sequences when Ghat tells his friend Deadra about the events that lead to him killing FatherMother.Now, let's talk about the gameplay. As I mentioned above, it's a First Person Brawler, which means that for most of the game you'll be fighting with your fists. There's weapons, too, and areas in which you're required to use them, but for most of the game, it's a lot more satisfying to simply punch your way out. Progression is fairly linear, you'll go from point A to point B, fighting enemies in the middle, with some cutscenes here and there adding more story. Don't take that as a negative, though! It works fine enough for this game.The game also has a challenge mode, unlocked through story progression, with two distinct types: tower and pit. In the Tower challenge levels, you'll fight through five floors, each one filled with different enemies, and you must reach the top in the shortest amout of time possible, while losing very little health; even then, if you do lose some health in a floor, you'll gain some of it back for the next one. The Pit challenge levels have you going down a pit, trying to reach the bottom without killing yourself (if you drop from too high, you'll die), while some enemies try to fight you.I guess I should talk about the art style, which is quite unique; you'll find a world filled with bizarre environments and creatures; even some of the most "normal" characters, like Ghat or Deadra, have their bits of weirdness. And the soundtrack is excellent, I should say, with some really good tracks playing during the fight sequences. All of this adds to making Zeno Clash a really good game.Of course, not everything is positive; even though I enjoyed the game a lot, it seems to have some issues with hit detection: sometimes I would attack an enemy thinking that my fist would hit them, only to hit thin air, while in other cases, believing to be out of reach, some enemies have managed to hit me. Even then, this isn't noticeable for most of the game.So, to conclude, I can say I recommend Zeno Clash.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												One of my first purchases here on Steam. I believe it was back in 2009 if I remember correctly and it did have a very nice discount on it so it was immediately in my basket.Zeno Clash is an ambitious first person shooter game developed by ACE Team and released in 2009. The game uses the modified version of the Source Engine so it runs very well and while it is somewhat of an aged engine it still - in my opinion - looks good. Interestingly, rarely do you have the chance to use weapons with projectiles; emphasis is on melee combat and you do have the chance to use some clubs or other heavy weapons beside your fists. Combat is simple but very smooth - the game is very linear and as it is an independent game you can already guess it is quite short.Story-wise the game is rather silly - it puts you in the shoes of Ghat who is banished from his home after an attempt to kill Father-Mother. Yes, this creature is his father and mother as it seems the entire population of Ghat's settlement was raised by this hermaphroditic creature. Although banished, Ghat wishes to uncover the truth as to what really happened and what secret lies with the family.Anyways, combat is quite good and the game has a challenge option with levels of a tower to compete against a series of enemies. This is getting difficult gradually - a nice way to pass time once the story mode is finished.Zeno Clash is somewhat mediocre, but I believe the result of an original idea. If it is on sale this is a highly recommended game.

												This game has too many cool ideas and never fleshes them out enough to actually make an interesting story! Also, the plot twist is crap and so is the whole motivation behind the main character. The dialoag is all forced and the enitre game is just one bad mistake after another.What do it mean? Here's an example: This game allows you to shoot enemies with various weapons and then switch them out as you fight or stow them and your your fists. Sounds cool right? NOPE!!! The Lock Target button is mapped to the Swap Target button and the Pick Up New Weapon action. THE FREAKIN "E" key! So when your rushing up to a guy who just dropped his much better weapon, you instinctively press the E key to snap it up. ERRRRT Now youre locked onto the nearest enemy and youre now open for an attack CUZ YOUVE STILL GOT THE CRAPPY FISH PISTOLS.4/10 Save Your Money.

Posted: December 27, 2014
												A true hidden gem that deserves so much more recognition. I haven't seen such hauntingly alien landscapes and settings since Morrowind, the visual desing in this game is excellent with every location being memorable and every character becoming quickly recognizable at a glance. The combat is fresh, easy to learn but difficult to master and very satisfying which is amazing when you consider this is a first person fighting game! Even the plot feels like something vibrant and different, while fairly simple and some what predictable, you are presented with a rich and detailed world that oozes life and history but never feels the need to bog things down explaining itself. The closest thing I can think of to bring up as criticism is that the sound design is very lacking, the music is so forgettable that it may as well not be there and the voice actors seem strictly amateur. It's also very short, there is some replay value with multiple endings and a challenge mode but it's still only a few afternoons worth of play. These are however very minor flaws in an otherwise beautiful game.At the price this goes for during sales you owe it to yourself to experience this.
