Posted: February 16, 2014
												I'm glad to see this game get a sequel... you can read a wide variety of reviews that love the game or hate the game but one thing that's a constant is they always give the game props for originality and creativity.  The art direction is very enjoyable to me, and if you're a fan of current craze "Chivalry" then you'll find a lot to enjoy in this universe.  Three boners out of five.

Posted: October 8, 2011
												It's kind of like if double dragon was an fps, and  it was set in some universe which is so ♥♥♥♥ing outlandishly weird that it manages to make sense in it's own way. The fighting mechanics are quite unique and they feel intuitive but without sacrificing options. I haven't been as impressed by a melee fighting system since Mount and Blade tbh. The story is whacky and entertaining too. Be warned that most the gameplay is brawling against opponents. There's some shooting segments and a part which plays almost like a tower defence kind of thing without towers, but in my opinion the brawling mechanics are good enough to justify the game being mostly just that - brawling.Even if you don't find it completely enjoyable, it's just too weird and unique of a game not to play through to see what it's like.

Posted: August 12, 2011
												While playing the Riddick games, I though "hey, these games have really good fps fighting mechanics! Actually, I think these games shouldn't even feature weapons at all." The fps fighting mechanics seemed so great I couldn't even think how someone could improve them.And then I played Zeno Clash, and man, this game is wonderful. There are a few problems (the arenas are too closed - maube they should be bigger, with more space to maneuver -, the stamina is too short), but, in general, this is one of the very few 3d brawlers (like Die Hard Arcade and God Hand) that really capture that "impact feel" you get playing games 2d brawlers like Streets of Rage 2, Denjin Makai, Sengoku 3 and other classics. When you give a punch in this game, you can really feel it. Plus, the fights here are crude and dirty: you can kick downed oponents, throw one enemy to another, break huge hammers in their heads...It is a must play, even if it's only for the imaginative visuals. Go punch some Corwids, now.

Posted: November 26, 2010
												This game is nearly as unique as its environment. It's a first person puncher set int a world that nobody has seen before. It has the potential to change your nightmares and dreams just by looking at the first level. But they didn't stop at just making everything look amazing and unique. They instead went further, making it an excellent fighitng game. While some parts are poorly made, the vast majority of the game is excellent and due to the relatively bite sized episdes of the game, you'll never find yourself hating the game over these small frustrations. If you don't trust me, at least try the demo and you'll see how much stress relief there is for punching a bird in the face. Over and over.

Posted: December 30, 2013
												This game is just weirdly addicting. I enjoyed the art style, although very strange, and I thought that the combat was satisfying. Although it's fairly short, I was happy with the game over-all and it left me wanting to play the second game. The story is very weird and possibly off putting to some, (warning: you will fight the same people over and over, but in different circumstances and with new challenges added in) but it comes together in the end fairly well and can be challenging at times.  Seeing as like only 5 guys made this game I was thoroughly impressed and glad that I played it. I'm looking forward to playing the second installment in the coming months. I got them both on a Humble Bundle sell and so far my money was definitely well spent.

Posted: July 16, 2012
												ZenoClash is one of those rare games in the industry which doesn't just play follow the leader. It is a truely innovative game and I found it to be a very enjoyable experience. To briefly describe the gameplay, imagine a wrestling game crossed with a first person shooter and dipped in a vat of Salvador Dali's immagination. Basically there are a series of battles in which you use your fists, kicks, grabs and sometimes weapons, both melee and ranged. The systems are complex and feel really rewarding when mastered.  Some may find the systems a little difficult to master, I know it took me several hours of gameplay to begin to feel competent. If you enjoy a challenge that shouldn't put you off this game.The setting is spectacular, very odd and unique and not an art style you see in many games. The world is rich and although there is not a lot of story the world itself and the design of the world makes the game a richer experience.Ran out of room, verdict, BUY IT!

Posted: March 9, 2013
												Zeno Clash. I'll have to admit I only picked up this game because it was insanely cheap (£0.59) . Having no expectations for the game or no prior knowledge about the game I was presently surprised by what this game had to offer. The story of this game is so damn trippy you will need to buy this game yourself to experiance its awesomely weirdness. The best part about Zeno Clash is its combat system. It is a beat em up but in first person. You can do a variety of punches ranging from jabs to HOLY♥♥♥♥♥♥YOU JUST MADE THAT GUY FLY ACROSS THE SCREEN. When you successfully pull off harder punches you get a sastifying crunch as you see your enemies face turn into jelly. There are also some guns in the game which are really awkward and are no where near as sastifying to use. I'd recommend this game to people looking for something different it is a short game but baring in mind I got it really cheap on a steam sale im sure you could aswell.

Posted: July 14, 2011
												The way I see it, there four strong reasons to get this game:1) The art style is gorgeous. The set design is great and the environments are enormously varied from chapter to chapter and scene to scene. It is thematically coherent but at the same time constantly surprising. Many of the locations are designed to evoke feelings, and are very immersive.2) The story is involving! The plot is cohesive and engaging. The characters are well-written and multifaceted, with growth over the story arc. It didn't take long for me to find myself showing concern for the wellbeing of these characters, in particular that of the female lead.3) Game mechanics are different. Although this game is at heart an FPS, most of your combat will be brawling. The melee fighting system is different but interesting, and challenging enough to keep you interested through the game.4) Source Engine! Yes Zeno Clash uses the same engine as HL2. It's familiar, you know how it acts, and it feels right.Recommended.

												Some people think that Half-Life 2 constantly changes its gameplay and always stays engaging  because of it. Well, screw them. Here you will get a new location and different gameplay mechanics every ten minutes. And literally kick some♥♥♥♥♥ And participate in an intriguing story somewhere in between the Discworld Noir and those logic puzzles about the flowers which are in fact the green animals who drink vodka.  And if anything needs praising, it's the idea to create a nonsential weird world so the players could say "WTF" and feel like kids again. The execution [of everything] isn't perfect, but it still beats most of things ever AMG's Alice included. Posted: April 22, 2012
												A really non-traditional story here will a lot of unconventional gameplay.  It's largely melee based combat and it has a really good feel.  The story really is far out there but ACE Team did a great job bringing the madness to a close at the end.  I really enjoyed the game, though it's mostly an on-rails experience.Doing the ladder missions is really awesome and gives you a lot of room to experiment with all the different melee attacks you've learned throughout the game.I'd recommend this game to anyone even at full price.  It's worf it.

Posted: October 31, 2011
												Zeno Clash is a weird game.  "Weird" is definitely the best adjective to describe it.  It's an odd game with odd characters in an odd world.  The game is made in the Source Engine, but the visuals are strikingly different from other games from the same engine, like Half Life 2 or Vampire: The Masquerade.  The game is a string of arcade-esque fights with guns and fists, all in first-person.  Zeno Clash is actually one of the only games to do fist fighting correctly in first person, and it does it well.  While Zeno Clash is very short, the story clocking only three to four hours, it does have a challange mode and varying difficulty levels.  Even if it costs too much at full price, it's undoubtably worth it on sale.

Posted: July 19, 2011
												An excellent Indie-Game based on the Source Engine with gripping first-person melee combat and a deep storyline set in a stone age fantasy world. Unfortunately the voice acting (luckily english only) is not as good as you could be familiar with from other games. Another disadvantage is the fact that shooter experienced players can finish it in 5 hours (or less). There is a challenge mode where you can proof your melee combat skills and allows you to post your highscore in your Steam Friends network.If you are looking for some hours of fun, excitement and brawl in an odd fantasy world, Zeno Clash is _the_ game for you xD

Posted: November 26, 2011
												Zeno Clash is a First-Person-Fighter whose faults (including short playtime--I did it in about 3 hours--and sometimes irritating combat) are well outshone by its strange visuals and setting. Zeno Clash uses Fantasy to its best potential and rather than stuff more Orcs, Elves, and Dwarves down your throat it comes up with a wholly unique setting that is both striking and at time mesmerizing. To give you an idea of what the game is really like, I'll quote my favorite piece of dialogue. "The Corwids are not slaves of reality; so they can be insane... Here I met Oxameter. Oxameter just walks in a straight line without letting anything change his path, and that's what Oxameter does. There was also Helim. Helim needed to be invisible, so he removed the eyes from anything that could see him."

												Zeno Clash can be summarized in two words - freaky weird. 												This is some weird♥♥♥♥♥♥ man. I can't remember the last time I played such an odd, unique game. The design of the characters and environments are mindblowingly unique. The story is sporadic, though. The combat can be broken into two points. Gunplay = Source. No problems. Posted: March 11, 2012
												A true gem! Apart from the obvious "wtf" aspect of the art style (contestant for the best use of Source 2date imo) & the bizarre characters & story, this game has a hand 2 hand combat system that can put 3A titles to shame. While ranged and melee weapons are present the heart of the combat lies in good ol' fist fights, where you have to be thinking on your feet in order to survive. It is amazing how they've managed to make each part of the h2h combat system tacticaly valid, esp block/evade where usualy one option tends to overshadow the other. Hits also have some "weight" to them as opponents will react accordingly to each thumping blow.  Another + is the iclusion of a tower mode where you'll be focusing solely on the combat. Only drawback is the game's length: approx 5 hrs for the sp story. All in all one of the most unique games out there. Def give this 1 a shot!

There is a challenge mode where you can proof your melee combat skills and allows you to post your highscore in your Steam Friends network.If you are looking for some hours of fun, excitement and brawl in an odd fantasy world, Zeno Clash is _the_ game for you xD

												The first reaction that I had by beginning Zeno Clash was "what the ♥♥♥♥ is that thing????!". At the very end of the game, I was like “what the ♥♥♥♥ did I just play ????”The story takes place in a strange world mixing Prehistory and Fantasy, Zenozoik, and where the hero, Ghat, avoids his family having propped up its "father" together with Deadra, his girlfriend, who sticks him throughout the adventure. To there, everything goes well.Except that the "Father", named "Father-mother" in the story, is a sort of mutant bird-human of 3 meters high, and that your "brothers" and "sisters" can be as well normal human beings as mutants human -lizards / birds / ogres / pigs / elephants / bear / insert here the animal of your choice...So we control Ghat during his trip, during which he is going to meet, besides the members of his beautiful family: explosive squirrels, mutants-pigs / cats even musicians, specters-zombies throwing blue fireballs, crabs, murderer... Yes the bestiary is rather wide. And we can even kill pets, as the chickens or the pigs, with a good kick in the belly; it is an achievement on Steam.More seriously, Zeno Clash is a game of fight; the fights will be generally launched by a big avatar with " X VS Y " as in a Tekken, Street Fighter and others.There are about 18 levels, very short. About 4 hours are required to see the end of the game at the normal level. Add 1 hour to make the Challenge mode, which is a Tower full of the various enemies you have met during the campaign mode.There are some weapons (sword, hammer, crossbow, pistols, rifle, grenades), which will be useful in some situations (snipers, big guys). But, between us, the fights will take place essentially hand to hand. Because it is funnier, more interesting and more powerful.The game is easy to understand, I played the Normal level, but I would be able to start with a higher difficulty without problems. You just have to use the fight tricks (counter-attack, dodging…) which are explained to us in the first levels, and it will be easy.The universe is very nice, graphics and musics are good. The scenario is correct, but it will let you perplexed.Conclusion: A weird game. But a good game.

Posted: May 16, 2015
												Zeno Clash is a fantastic first person fighter in a truly oddball setting. In Zeno Clash, you play as Ghat, one human in a tribe of varying races raised by the asexual creature "father mother". After attacking Father Mother, you and your surprisingly loyal "beetle antlers-in hair" girlfriend Deadra, have to fight to survive after Father Mother's children come after you.It's a simple story, and Zeno Clash is a odd game in a strange, strange world populated by animal hybrid creatures, odd weapons made out of animal bones and beautiful scenery straight out of an acid trip.Despite all of that oddity though, the game itself is rather easy to get your head around. It's a first person fighter based around punches, kicks, combos, timing and defensive tactics over super moves or memorizing long combos. You will occasionally find weapons which you can use ranging from giant bone swords. to dual fish pistols. to even a really cool rifle made of bone and animal parts. You can use these pretty much for the entirety of a fight as they have infinite ammo (Unlike in Zeno Clash 2), but despite the occasional mandatory weapon section that betrays the game's source engine roots, Zeno Clash is still very much a first person brawler. The combat feels straight up visceral and impactful with just about every swing, block or throw you make. At times it feels a tad sluggish, The combat is fun, but my favorite element of the (admittedly linear) game is exploring this absolutely crazy world. What's interesting about Zeno Clash's setting is that it doesn't seem to be just contrived of an acid trip, genuine world building has been done here and it shows. Areas range from market towns full of thieves to outlands full of sky high elephant-giraffe-anteater-things, to a few areas I would actually rather not spoil, but every one feels fleshed out and varied.Did I mention the game is gorgeous by the way, even now? Colors seem to fade, merge and pop in a way only water color paintings can. This game has some of the prettiest skyboxes I've ever seen, especially for a source game. Overall, the art design is rather excellent. Just about every character, weapon, and creature feels perfectly in line with game's oddball style.It is the first game by an indie studio, so it's not without its rough spots. The voice actor for Deadra isn't all that great, small parts of the combat like recoveries feel a little sluggish, and the limitations of the source engine occasionally crop up, like rather small levels and loading screens halfway through areas. The fish pistols have this odd bug that still has yet to be fixed where the bottom row of bullet indicators is cut in half on the interface. The FOV is non-adjustable, although this is probably to add to immersion and because it changes mid-game actually mid combat. (This is a game where you can see your own feet, it is aiming for immersion.)Overall, Recommendation: If you even think you might like this, buy it. It's cheap at $10 and is well worth your time to at least play through the campaign once. If you are unsure, wishlist it and wait for a sale, as it usually drops down really, really low in price.If you are wondering about cost to time spent ratio, the campaign is about 4+ hours long, but there's tons to go back and see. There's also a Challenge tower that I didn't bother too much with but you may find intriguing.

Posted: May 11, 2015
												The combat is great, albeit very simple, the level design is good, and often pits you against interesting enemy/weapon combinations, everything is fun to use, everything looks great, and everything sounds great. The melee/ranged combat balance is very well done, and the game never gets dull.Now that the good bits are out of the way, let's go straight to the bad/disappointing bits.-The world of Zenozoik looks absolutely fantastic, mostly due to its very unusual, colorful and all-out insane art style.This causes a bit of a problem, which I guess is a very good problem to have : I want to see more of it ! Talk to characters, explore the wilderness , discover weird locations and even weirder inhabitants !Unfortunately, Zeno Clash is a very linear and straightforward game. You move forward, have an enemy encounter, you beat them up, and you repeat until the end of the level.I really wish the game was a standard FPS or had RPG elements that would allow me to explore it. It's such a shame to see what could be an amazing world to explore reduced to a pretty backdrop.-The game is pretty short, it took me about 3.5 hours to finish, without the challenges. This isn't really a problem as i feel it has quite a bit of replay value.-The voice acting is bad. Admittedly, it's bad in a cute way, like Deus Ex but a tad worse. The random use of made up    words like "kak" and "tef" don't help.-The boat level is boring. Fortunately it barely lasts 2 minutes, but you spend them looking left and right shooting at sand people who are throwing rocks at you.-There is a weird stutter when you move your mouse, it's not very noticeable but nonetheless annoying.-Unskippable cutscenes-The FOV is broken, but I made a guide to fix it :

												The fictional world of Zenoizoik is a strange one -- a hybrid of Mad Max dystopia and Flinstones outlandishness. But this first person fighter presents a world as cruel as it is fascinating. You play Ghat, a man on the run for murdering his own family. Posted: July 25, 2011
												Zeno Clash was developed by ACE Team, an entertainment software developer based in Santiago, Chile.  They're committed to making unique games that stand out for their originality and quality.  Zeno Clash is exactly that; the use of the Source engine makes for excellent graphics and  a quality feel, while it's unique art style, story line, and melee combat system really sets this game apart from your typical half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥console port.JohnCover gives you his recommendation.

Posted: April 13, 2015
												This is a First Person Brawler with a simple combat system, original and out of the ordinary art style. Featuring a 2-3 hour story mode and another hour of challenges. Graphics: The game uses the Source engine (Half Life 2) so it has limited but memorable scenes. The art style is astonishing and  aestheticly looks like a wierd dream. I really want to see the concept arts or a sketchbook from the creator. Technically the game looks okay. There are low res textures, jerky shadows and low poly stuff. But the caracter design, the weapons and the environment...man this game looks and feels really uniqe. Sound: The music just like the graphics fullfills this wierd dreamy athmosphere. There are many memorable moments thank to the great combination of them. Voice acting is cheesy but funny. The dialogues are genuinely funny and serious at the same time. The sound effects are basic public domain stuff.  Gameplay: Gameplay wise well... it's simple. The main scenario is arena fight. You get to a locked area and you have to defeat all the enemies. Imagine these like nodes in a graph. These nodes are connected by edges that are basically linear paths. And overall the game is linear and the level design is linear too. There is a turret section as well but still has the stong dreamy athmosphere so it's okay. You will encounter little enemies, normal enemies, normal enemies with weapons (melee, ranged), brutes and bosses.The little enemies are crabs, chickens and those big rabbit thingys. I think most of them just spit you acid liquid. Normal enemies are basically fighting partners. These guys can pick up weapons as well. Enemy vaiety is nice here because there are different models and fighting styles. Brutes are big, tough enemies and you better kill 'em with melee weapons. They take multiple hits as well. Bosses are easy battles, just like old times: wasd 'em and shoot 'em.You can shoot only in ADS otherwise you swing the weapon towards the enemy. You can throw the weapons as well. Mechanically these are the same as in other games but they feel strange and uniqe in a positive way.The melee system is simple and easy to learn. There are basic combos and advanced combos. The game does a good job teaching you these things in the tutorial sessions. There is a challenge tower for pro players. It's basically a fight fest. You have to climb the tower and defeat all the enemies. Things could get hard here... :) Replayability: As I mentioned the Singleplayer story mode is linear and each replay will be the same. But if you liked the story and the wierd things in it, I'm sure you'll give it another go. However the Challenge Tower is pure gameplay and fun and absolutely replayable.  Overall:  Pros:  Short but entertaining Singleplayer mode Visceral combat Simple and fun melle system Uniqe aesthetics Interesting art style Dreamy music Cons:  Short Singleplayer mode Lack of MP features Mediocre sound effects Nothing special in technical level Linear levels Verdict: A nice game from the indie developer, Ace Team. I had great fun with it. I recommend this game for those who like fighting games, wierd fiction, and for those who's time is short and want a short game.

Posted: April 30, 2015
												Take Mad Max, Dragonheart, and the Island of Dr Moreau and blend them all together and you'll come up with a game called Zeno Clash. The combat takes place from a first person perspective and allows for complex moves such as dodging and parrying. You get the option of using either your fists/melee or guns in most battles although some will limit you to one or the other. Story-wise, this game is pretty simplistic but the level and character design more than make up for it with some absolutely stunning yet totally bizarre visuals. The only detractor from the overall experience is that the voice acting is a bit corny and the game is fairly short. Definitely worth picking up at a fair price.

Posted: July 6, 2011
												At its core, Xeno Clash is a spiritual successor to arcade beat-em-up games. What sets it apart is the unique, fully-realized world and story the game punctuates the action with in scripted cutscenes and flashbacks that slowly reveal the central mystery of the plot. The game is powered by the Source engine, and true to its linage, the character work in these scenes is top-notch.The action in Xeno Clash takes place in the first-person, and you chain together punches and throws to form combos, while dodging the enemies' own swings. Besides hand-to-hand combat, you can also scoop up weapons dropped by your foes, such as pistols, a rifle, and grenades. Enemies usually come in waves, but you can easily lock your focus to a specific foe.The game itself is rather short, and can be finished in a few hours. There's a series of challenge levels to give the game some replay value. But Xeno Clash's presentation, artwork, and story differentiate enough that any gamer should give it a shot.

Posted: October 18, 2015
												Zeno Clash is a pretty good game. The world, as well as the artwork, is very unique. The story mode won't take you long to finish, though the game does offer challenge mode(which I have yet to explore). The combat system is an interesting facet of the game, allowing the player to target enemies to fight hand-to-hand with a choice of basic or power punches, as well as a block/dodge/counter system. The game also affords the player a couple of club weapons, as well as ranged weapons(with quite interesting design). That being said, it does feel shallow at times, and the targetting system has it's hiccups. The voice acting is well done for the most part(father-mother being nicely conveyed). Overall, a nice game. It doesn't provide too much content but offers enough of it in a unique, and quite refreshing way.

												A very wierd but very fun little game. Posted: July 14, 2012
												Zeno Clash is a First Person Brawler, as hard as that sounds to believe.  Each of the stages are set up as fights between you and enemies, all of which start off with a Street Fighter "VS" screen.  The game also features a couple of weapons, although they are usually used as utility to the actual fist fighting.  The game does actually have a story, although I'm not even going to try to explain it.  The artstyle is unique as well, combining tribal looks with a bit of smashed together 20th century sculpture.  The game is short, but also features an optional tower mode where you have to fight floors of enemies and progress up without dying.  If you like quirky indie games, you'll probably get a kick out of the few hours Zeno Clash offers.

												Think "Double Dragon FPS in a strange alien world" and you're pretty much there. This games combat system is amazing in its simplicity: Punches, kicks, grapples, parries, dodges and counters are all possible using standard FPS controls. Various items are at your disposal, such as unlikely firearms, 'skullbombs' and health pickups.An example of how fights play out: 


YouTube™ Video: Zenoclash: Gateway Brawl

Posted: December 12, 2014
												A pretty short first-person-beat'em-up-and-shooter.The beating people up and shooting at them part is pretty solid. The hand-to hand combat itself is decent and requires some skill, certainly more than we have seen in games like the Batman or the Assasins Creed series. You also get some blunt weapons which you can use, as well as some guns. There isn't a whole lot of the guns, but they all feel and act quite different, which helps vary the gameplay up a bit. Not that the gameplay is in need of that, the hand to hand combat is actually impressively immersive, I just really appreciate variety in gunplay ^^The game itself has a very odd, surreal, atmosphere, one of the guys below me called it "disjointed" and that description fits it perfectly. I liked it quite a lot, but I can see why it wouldn't appeal to everyone. The story, the envrioment and the characters are as strange as they are interesting, and even the "normal" enemies feel very unique design-wise. Apart from the story, which is very short (I beat it in like 3 hours!), there isn't really anything else to the game. The challenge mode may be able to entertain you for a while, but that's it.Overall, there isn't a lot of content, but the content that's there is very compelling and unique. The game is on sale quite frequently, so if you like brawlers or just games with a very unique and strange atmosphere, you owe it to yourself to pick it up.

StoryStrange, enjoyable, if a bit small in scale. It will make you want to shoot them all, and thats all I can ask for in a shooter.Final Score 8/10.A fun, strange shooter that will make you want to see what kind of weird zone you will see next. 												Take Mad Max, Dragonheart, and the Island of Dr Moreau and blend them all together and you'll come up with a game called Zeno Clash. The combat takes place from a first person perspective and allows for complex moves such as dodging and parrying. Posted: May 16, 2015
												Zeno Clash is a fantastic first person fighter in a truly oddball setting. In Zeno Clash, you play as Ghat, one human in a tribe of varying races raised by the asexual creature "father mother". After attacking Father Mother, you and your surprisingly loyal "beetle antlers-in hair" girlfriend Deadra, have to fight to survive after Father Mother's children come after you.It's a simple story, and Zeno Clash is a odd game in a strange, strange world populated by animal hybrid creatures, odd weapons made out of animal bones and beautiful scenery straight out of an acid trip.Despite all of that oddity though, the game itself is rather easy to get your head around. It's a first person fighter based around punches, kicks, combos, timing and defensive tactics over super moves or memorizing long combos. You will occasionally find weapons which you can use ranging from giant bone swords. to dual fish pistols. to even a really cool rifle made of bone and animal parts. You can use these pretty much for the entirety of a fight as they have infinite ammo (Unlike in Zeno Clash 2), but despite the occasional mandatory weapon section that betrays the game's source engine roots, Zeno Clash is still very much a first person brawler. The combat feels straight up visceral and impactful with just about every swing, block or throw you make. At times it feels a tad sluggish, The combat is fun, but my favorite element of the (admittedly linear) game is exploring this absolutely crazy world. What's interesting about Zeno Clash's setting is that it doesn't seem to be just contrived of an acid trip, genuine world building has been done here and it shows. Areas range from market towns full of thieves to outlands full of sky high elephant-giraffe-anteater-things, to a few areas I would actually rather not spoil, but every one feels fleshed out and varied.Did I mention the game is gorgeous by the way, even now? Colors seem to fade, merge and pop in a way only water color paintings can. This game has some of the prettiest skyboxes I've ever seen, especially for a source game. Overall, the art design is rather excellent. Just about every character, weapon, and creature feels perfectly in line with game's oddball style.It is the first game by an indie studio, so it's not without its rough spots. The voice actor for Deadra isn't all that great, small parts of the combat like recoveries feel a little sluggish, and the limitations of the source engine occasionally crop up, like rather small levels and loading screens halfway through areas. The fish pistols have this odd bug that still has yet to be fixed where the bottom row of bullet indicators is cut in half on the interface. The FOV is non-adjustable, although this is probably to add to immersion and because it changes mid-game actually mid combat. (This is a game where you can see your own feet, it is aiming for immersion.)Overall, Recommendation: If you even think you might like this, buy it. It's cheap at $10 and is well worth your time to at least play through the campaign once. If you are unsure, wishlist it and wait for a sale, as it usually drops down really, really low in price.If you are wondering about cost to time spent ratio, the campaign is about 4+ hours long, but there's tons to go back and see. There's also a Challenge tower that I didn't bother too much with but you may find intriguing.

Posted: May 11, 2015
												The combat is great, albeit very simple, the level design is good, and often pits you against interesting enemy/weapon combinations, everything is fun to use, everything looks great, and everything sounds great. The melee/ranged combat balance is very well done, and the game never gets dull.Now that the good bits are out of the way, let's go straight to the bad/disappointing bits.-The world of Zenozoik looks absolutely fantastic, mostly due to its very unusual, colorful and all-out insane art style.This causes a bit of a problem, which I guess is a very good problem to have : I want to see more of it ! Talk to characters, explore the wilderness , discover weird locations and even weirder inhabitants !Unfortunately, Zeno Clash is a very linear and straightforward game. You move forward, have an enemy encounter, you beat them up, and you repeat until the end of the level.I really wish the game was a standard FPS or had RPG elements that would allow me to explore it. It's such a shame to see what could be an amazing world to explore reduced to a pretty backdrop.-The game is pretty short, it took me about 3.5 hours to finish, without the challenges. This isn't really a problem as i feel it has quite a bit of replay value.-The voice acting is bad. Admittedly, it's bad in a cute way, like Deus Ex but a tad worse. The random use of made up    words like "kak" and "tef" don't help.-The boat level is boring. Fortunately it barely lasts 2 minutes, but you spend them looking left and right shooting at sand people who are throwing rocks at you.-There is a weird stutter when you move your mouse, it's not very noticeable but nonetheless annoying.-Unskippable cutscenes-The FOV is broken, but I made a guide to fix it :

Having finished the game and looking back and the strange journey that happened I can't help to hope that others experience it to.If you look beyond the bizare art direction, creepy and odd characters, you will find an amazing and bold story. The strength of the art direction is its characters is that it opens up to story. The world is actually kind of beautiful, in its own brutal kind of way. Play it as a medium length shooter, enjoy the story and seeing some quirky and odd characters. GraphicsKind of an older game so don't expect to be blown away. Once you get used to it you really do kind of smile at its strange way of seeing things.GameplayEnjoyable. You advance at a nice pace and the game really makes you feel like you are progressing.SoundHonestly I can't remember the sound. I can't remember being disapointed by it or it grating on me. So theres that.Game LengthId say its medium length. You could get about two to three days out of it. But you can beat it in a sitting if you have time. StoryStrange, enjoyable, if a bit small in scale. It will make you want to shoot them all, and thats all I can ask for in a shooter.Final Score 8/10.A fun, strange shooter that will make you want to see what kind of weird zone you will see next. Characters are bonkers. Bad guys make you want to unload clips into them, good guys will make you want to not kill them. Try it, I recommend it.

Posted: November 27, 2014
												very linear levels with not much exploration. however, the unique graphics, sound, and story more than make up for the lack of level exploration. Each scene is basically a deathmatch versus any number of strange enemies with a brief story intermission before the next battle. The maps for each of these battles is a small arena sized area where you usaually end up kiting with ranged weapons and/or beating baddies senseless with your fists. This is one of the few games where graphics and sound make up for game design in the pure strangeness of it, combined with being dropped into an unknown lore that is bizarre. Highly recommended to play while not sober as it seems it was designed while under the influence of god knows what.

Posted: November 30, 2014
												A fast paced brawler that reminded me of older games with a nice mix of hard fighting and annoying rules. A good game by it's own right when you're able to take the bitter pills it makes you swallow. Almost all the combat is hand-to-hand fighting with some guns to play with. This makes for the funnest part of the game play, hard hitting and somewhat tactical combat that you can really get stuck into. However, a boring rail shooting level and 'oh so exciting' sewer level creep in to muck up some ofthe gameplay. The occasional big 'brute' style enemy pops up to force you to play whack-with-stick combat that slows down gameplay annoyingly. HOWEVER, for the fun of the main combat, which you do the most, it's a worthwhile game for the fun brawling focus. Oh, and the story is kinda neat, even if it's really kinda screwy.Pro:-Dayum that brawling combat is fun-The story's twist is kind of interesting, even if...Con:-... It's easy to forget it during the fighting.-Brutes are annoying to fight, but not THAT unpleasantOf note:-Most bosses force you to fight with ranged weapons to beat them, a few force you to know the counter system well without forcing you to use it.-The game's got a decent tutorial that's broken up a bit.-The game is as weird as it is in the screenshots, but it's not THAT 'weird'. Except the storyline is.

Posted: November 26, 2010
												This game is nearly as unique as its environment. It's a first person puncher set int a world that nobody has seen before. It has the potential to change your nightmares and dreams just by looking at the first level. But they didn't stop at just making everything look amazing and unique. They instead went further, making it an excellent fighitng game. While some parts are poorly made, the vast majority of the game is excellent and due to the relatively bite sized episdes of the game, you'll never find yourself hating the game over these small frustrations. If you don't trust me, at least try the demo and you'll see how much stress relief there is for punching a bird in the face. Over and over.

Posted: December 30, 2013
												This game is just weirdly addicting. I enjoyed the art style, although very strange, and I thought that the combat was satisfying. Although it's fairly short, I was happy with the game over-all and it left me wanting to play the second game. The story is very weird and possibly off putting to some, (warning: you will fight the same people over and over, but in different circumstances and with new challenges added in) but it comes together in the end fairly well and can be challenging at times.  Seeing as like only 5 guys made this game I was thoroughly impressed and glad that I played it. I'm looking forward to playing the second installment in the coming months. I got them both on a Humble Bundle sell and so far my money was definitely well spent.

Posted: July 16, 2012
												ZenoClash is one of those rare games in the industry which doesn't just play follow the leader. It is a truely innovative game and I found it to be a very enjoyable experience. To briefly describe the gameplay, imagine a wrestling game crossed with a first person shooter and dipped in a vat of Salvador Dali's immagination. Basically there are a series of battles in which you use your fists, kicks, grabs and sometimes weapons, both melee and ranged. The systems are complex and feel really rewarding when mastered.  Some may find the systems a little difficult to master, I know it took me several hours of gameplay to begin to feel competent. If you enjoy a challenge that shouldn't put you off this game.The setting is spectacular, very odd and unique and not an art style you see in many games. The world is rich and although there is not a lot of story the world itself and the design of the world makes the game a richer experience.Ran out of room, verdict, BUY IT!

Posted: February 14, 2012
												Think "Double Dragon FPS in a strange alien world" and you're pretty much there. This games combat system is amazing in its simplicity: Punches, kicks, grapples, parries, dodges and counters are all possible using standard FPS controls. Much like any traditional beat 'em up, the game consists of a simple story presented in a series of stages. Various items are at your disposal, such as unlikely firearms, 'skullbombs' and health pickups.An example of how fights play out: 


YouTube™ Video: Zenoclash: Gateway Brawl 

			Views: 24		

			Gameplay video for one of the first fights in Zeno Clash.		

The art style is absolutely crazy, the city of Halstedom being a prime example: A chaotic mishmash of various structures that all seem to be made out of different materials. Much like the city, no two characters look alike. Out of all the wierd alien creatures you'll find, there are a few visibly human specimens, but even they all look completely different.Highly recommend if you enjoyed those oldschool beat 'em ups.

Posted: August 1, 2013
												Mechanics: It's a melee brawler with some wierd but cool looking guns. The fist fighting it really good and I couldn't ask any more or less from it. The guns seem to act like they should: Wood, bones, stone, and some metal all clashed together to make some kind of contraption that shoots skulls or stones.Pacing: It gives you a typical tutorial but makes it a little funny (Useing headless chickens as target practice) and it goes by fairly quickly. You are met with actual combat about a couple minutes into the game and it is challenging and fun. After some 1 v 3 or 1 v 1 fights you are met with a boss, it isn't too hard but it's not too easy so it's a good fight. The pacing in this game seems pretty good and introduces things to you at a good rate.Story: You somehow killed your mother and father and you millions of sisters and brothers are coming to get revenge. They send everything at you to stop you while you escape with what I presume is one of your sisters or a loved one. Voice acting is meh but I don't see that as a bad or a good thing. The story over all seems decent and is sure to be an enjoyable one.Summary: The game so far is very enjoyable. The combat is good and it keeps things new and fun. The story is nothing to praise but it is at least enjoyable. Overall the game is pretty good with few to no problems. I did expirence some lightless ragdolls while I was playing but that is not too big. Graphically, you should't expect much: It's a source game, from and indie dev, and it was made some years back.8/10: Really good game with little problems, it's melee combat is really nice and it's an enjoyable expirence.To clarify: 9/10: spectacular, 10/10 Perfect with little to no problems and was fun and enjoyable throughout every piece of the game. A 5/10 would be like: It's mechanics do what they are suppose to do and the game does nothing special in general. 1/10 would be: I only enjoyed one small part of this game. 0/10 would be KILL ME AND THIS GAME. 8/10 simply just means that It had good mechanics but had nothing special in some other things.

Posted: August 9, 2014
												Zeno Clash is good because it's interesting, and not because it's particularly well made. It doesn't prooperlysupport controllers without some config file tweaking and even then you need a mouse to load your save. The easy difficulty can get pretty hard and autosaves can put you in a tough spot (fortunately, there's two so you can go back a bit further). The combat is interesting, although I found it hard to dodge because it's a two-action sequence (block and then move) instead of a chord or single button. For controller users, there's no auto-aim for ranged weapons, I couldn't get the sensitivity low enough for precise aiming, and the reticle is hard to see so shooting can be difficult.There's other minor things that feel unpolished like delays after finishing a fight where nothing happens and the bad voice acting of the main character, but I still like Zeno Clash because it feels so different. Your companion's voice acting is great, many of the other characters are good, the mix of melee and ranged combat works well enough, the world is beautiful and strange, and the struggle of the protagonist (while not sold through the acting) is interesting and isn't the standards save-the-world cliche.I finished the game on easy with a controller, but used buddha mode (through the console) to get through some tough battles (like the infuriating Hunter).

It's a creative game that may be a bit short, yet in and of itself is very filling.I highly suggest buying it, and the sequal. Both are great games that have a great story.

Posted: January 15, 2012
												A very wierd but very fun little game.  There aren't alot of first person adventure/fighting games out there - probably for good reason - the mechanics are a bit strange and hard to get used to, but they can be alot of fun once you get into the swing of things.The real highlight for this game, however, is the colorful and original world it is set in.  The blurb calls it "punk-fantasy," which falls pretty short of quantifying just how oddball this game is.  The strange characters, fantastic creatures, and bizzare weapons all feel like they are referencing a deep and well established mythology - but one that is almost entirely alien to me.There are a few issues with focus and pacing but overall this is a great game that is worth the $15 sticker price.  8/10

Posted: May 30, 2012
												Zeno Clash is a rather unique take on the first-person view one commonly sees nowadays in the FPS genre. It's a first-person fighter, where the player ends up using his fists more than handmade weapons. The world of Zenozoic is one where metal is hardly seen; in its place is bone, stone and preserved guts, forming an incredibly strange world where clans vie for power. Rooster blood has the same effect as alcohol here and everyone knows fisticuffs - coincidence? I think not. The storyline seemed a bit lacking, but the gameplay is where it's at. A challenge worthy of any gamer worth his salt.

Posted: January 1, 2012
												It's a weird, frustrating, repulsive and beautiful game that will stick with me for a long time. It's not like anything you've played before, from the brawling gameplay to environments that seem drawn alternately from dreams, '60s sci-fi, and the artist getting sunstroke at a busy farm. The game is suggestive and evokes more than it tells, but there seems to be an underlying logic to the enigma of a story on which the game's journey is built. I highly recommend this game. It's cheap, and worth the 5-6 strange hours you'll put into it.

Posted: April 9, 2013
												Imagine if Dr.Seuss' muddle puddle tweetle poodle beetle noodle bottle paddle battle was real, and more like Thunder Dome from Mad Max. Now you've got Zeno Clash.It's a highly stylized first person brawler. It feels kind of odd to put that much detail and style into something that you don't look at while you punch everyone, but when you have time to stop to smell the blood spattered roses, it's a nice looking place. The story is a bit meh, and just goes so deep into this worlds bizzare lore that it gets a bit muddled. Really it's just for playing through once and going "well that was interesting", then never touching it again.Lets hope Zeno Clash 2 is better.On the other hand, if Zeno Clash 2 is set in the same world, maybe playing this just to get into the lore would be a good idea.

Posted: November 26, 2010
												This game is nearly as unique as its environment. It's a first person puncher set int a world that nobody has seen before. It has the potential to change your nightmares and dreams just by looking at the first level. But they didn't stop at just making everything look amazing and unique. They instead went further, making it an excellent fighitng game. While some parts are poorly made, the vast majority of the game is excellent and due to the relatively bite sized episdes of the game, you'll never find yourself hating the game over these small frustrations. If you don't trust me, at least try the demo and you'll see how much stress relief there is for punching a bird in the face. Over and over.

												very linear levels with not much exploration. however, the unique graphics, sound, and story more than make up for the lack of level exploration. Each scene is basically a deathmatch versus any number of strange enemies with a brief story intermission before the next battle. The maps for each of these battles is a small arena sized area where you usaually end up kiting with ranged weapons and/or beating baddies senseless with your fists. This is one of the few games where graphics and sound make up for game design in the pure strangeness of it, combined with being dropped into an unknown lore that is bizarre. Highly recommended to play while not sober as it seems it was designed while under the influence of god knows what.

Posted: December 2, 2014
												A difficult game to review. Having finished the game and looking back and the strange journey that happened I can't help to hope that others experience it to.If you look beyond the bizare art direction, creepy and odd characters, you will find an amazing and bold story. The strength of the art direction is its characters is that it opens up to story. The world is actually kind of beautiful, in its own brutal kind of way. Play it as a medium length shooter, enjoy the story and seeing some quirky and odd characters. GraphicsKind of an older game so don't expect to be blown away. Once you get used to it you really do kind of smile at its strange way of seeing things.GameplayEnjoyable. You advance at a nice pace and the game really makes you feel like you are progressing.SoundHonestly I can't remember the sound. I can't remember being disapointed by it or it grating on me. So theres that.Game LengthId say its medium length. You could get about two to three days out of it. But you can beat it in a sitting if you have time. StoryStrange, enjoyable, if a bit small in scale. It will make you want to shoot them all, and thats all I can ask for in a shooter.Final Score 8/10.A fun, strange shooter that will make you want to see what kind of weird zone you will see next. Characters are bonkers. Bad guys make you want to unload clips into them, good guys will make you want to not kill them. Try it, I recommend it.

Posted: August 9, 2014
												Zeno Clash is good because it's interesting, and not because it's particularly well made. It doesn't prooperlysupport controllers without some config file tweaking and even then you need a mouse to load your save. The easy difficulty can get pretty hard and autosaves can put you in a tough spot (fortunately, there's two so you can go back a bit further). The combat is interesting, although I found it hard to dodge because it's a two-action sequence (block and then move) instead of a chord or single button. For controller users, there's no auto-aim for ranged weapons, I couldn't get the sensitivity low enough for precise aiming, and the reticle is hard to see so shooting can be difficult.There's other minor things that feel unpolished like delays after finishing a fight where nothing happens and the bad voice acting of the main character, but I still like Zeno Clash because it feels so different. Your companion's voice acting is great, many of the other characters are good, the mix of melee and ranged combat works well enough, the world is beautiful and strange, and the struggle of the protagonist (while not sold through the acting) is interesting and isn't the standards save-the-world cliche.I finished the game on easy with a controller, but used buddha mode (through the console) to get through some tough battles (like the infuriating Hunter).

Posted: January 20, 2011
												Pros: Bizarre, unexpected, tons of personality and a lot of fun. Visceral first-person melee mechanics make combat very unique and engaging. Nightmarish character design and creepy voicework contributes highly to the game's fascinatingly surreal ambience.Cons: The small levels and strict linearity in progression are disappointing since the world's imaginative environments would be a blast to explore. Also, gamplay can feel repetitive at times since other than dialogue, there is little to break up the consecutive bouts of combat. Some elements of adventuring and exploration would add much to the experience. The game is a bit on the short side with the main story clocking in at about 4-5 hours.Overall, Zeno Clash is well worth playing and is an experience that is sure to stick with you. I hope there is a sequel.

Posted: March 11, 2013
												Zeno Clash can be summarized in two words - freaky weird. Imaginative setting that somehow manages to give the impression that you've only just scratched the surface of the world of Zenozoik (and beyond) along with its eerily disturbing and eccentric characters result in a unique experience overall. That's not to say everything deserves praise though, especially in the mechanics department. First-person melee combat is awkward especially with its overreliance on somewhat stubborn focus mode that takes some time getting used to in order to avoid frustration. Not to mention how short the game is, probably as a result of obviously being ACE Team's first effort and consequence their choice to go for a surreal one-time experience.

I found it refreshingly different from any other game I have ever played.

Posted: January 31, 2012
												Zeno clash is without a doubt the weirdest game I have ever played, in the most positive sense. The absurdistic world that you venture through never ceased to surprise me, and is at times strangely familiar. The music in Zenoclash is as weird as everything else in this game, and really seals the atmosphere. The voice acting sounds a bit shoddy though, although that might be intentional. I'm not really sure if it's a good or a bad thing, but I suppose it's another small contributor to the strangest, most bizare atmosphere you will ever encounter in a computergame. The game offers a unique experience to the player. The game may be a bit short, (you can probably finish the game in about 5 hours or so) but after finishing the storyline, you can also give the "tower challenges" a try. The tower challenges are basically a sort of gauntlet in which you fight against all the enemies which you have encountered during the storyline. I would give this game 78/100.

Posted: April 10, 2016
 DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine Zeno Clash is a weird game, it's one of those games that is weird and unique in it's own way. Zeno Clash is developed and published by ACE Team, the same people behind the wonderful rock game Rock of Ages, this was there first ever game and it was developed using Valve's Source engine which you can tell from the settings menu and subtitlesThe story follows Ghat as he is one of the thousands of brothers and sisters of Father-Mother, the game starts as you see Father-Mother die right before you're eyes, however, that's not the end of him-her. And after you run away from you're family, you will find out some secrets regarding your Father-Mother. The story isn't the best but get's the job doneThe game's graphics are wonderful. Weird and creepy but magnificent and unique, although the game uses the Source engine, you can't tell except from the settings menu and subtitles. All the environments, characters and enemies are unique in their own way and I praise ACE Team for making such a weird but unique game!The music and sound are also top notch, very well composed. The only thing I would complain about is the combat and gunplay. It's awkward and hard to fight enemies, plus you get hit from all sides which if you're own low health, you'd be dead in an instant, also, whilst fighting you focus on one enemy and that enemy only, and if you need to move away to find some health you can't...Another thing I would complain about is the length, it's short and I finished the game in one whole sitting. If it were a bit longer I wouldn't have complained about the length, but maybe it's a good thingOverall, Zeno Clash is an odd yet fun game to play in one whole sitting, and if you are looking for more, why not play it's sequel Zeno Clash 2 after playing the first one! RECOMMENDED :)

Posted: March 12, 2016
												This game is weird, just so damn weird. I have fun playing it as the combat mechanics is new although I wont say spectacular. The characters, setting and soundtrack etc on the other hand are as I said above weird, it is as if someone created the game by joining pieces of his dreams together. I would recommend this game had it not been so buggy.,,,,and the bugs are too glaring to ignore. The hit detection is ridiculously absurd, enemies fall into planes where you cant reach them, the triggered events do not trigger ( twice in a row in a climatic part of the game)....and heck even the credits are buggy......Play this game only if you want something different but if you want a nice experience, I wouldnt recommend,.Plus it is short, my hours are due to me farming cards.

Posted: February 19, 2016
												I think this game has my favourite setting of any game I've played. It manages to combine a native, pre-historic setting with post apocalyptic themes. Every area you visit is unique and stunning to look at. The game progresses linearly, going from one area to another fighting a handful of enemies. This may sound dull, but the combat is excellent. I can only compare it to dark souls and chivalry. You won't get by just spamming the hit button, you'll need to use your surroundings, kite your enemies (who will gang up on you otherwise), block and dodge. The weapons are also quite fun to use and vary enough that you won't get bored using the same ones over and over. The only weakness in the combat was the boss' and big enemies. They all use the same ai which can easily be beaten by just running circles around them whilst hitting them repeatedly. The story is interesting and actually made me want to find out what happened and the ending feels very rewarding. Git it.

												The way I see it, there four strong reasons to get this game:1) The art style is gorgeous. The set design is great and the environments are enormously varied from chapter to chapter and scene to scene. It is thematically coherent but at the same time constantly surprising. Many of the locations are designed to evoke feelings, and are very immersive.2) The story is involving! The plot is cohesive and engaging. The characters are well-written and multifaceted, with growth over the story arc. It didn't take long for me to find myself showing concern for the wellbeing of these characters, in particular that of the female lead.3) Game mechanics are different. Although this game is at heart an FPS, most of your combat will be brawling. The melee fighting system is different but interesting, and challenging enough to keep you interested through the game.4) Source Engine! Yes Zeno Clash uses the same engine as HL2. It's familiar, you know how it acts, and it feels right.Recommended.

Posted: May 16, 2015
												Zeno Clash is a fantastic first person fighter in a truly oddball setting. In Zeno Clash, you play as Ghat, one human in a tribe of varying races raised by the asexual creature "father mother". After attacking Father Mother, you and your surprisingly loyal "beetle antlers-in hair" girlfriend Deadra, have to fight to survive after Father Mother's children come after you.It's a simple story, and Zeno Clash is a odd game in a strange, strange world populated by animal hybrid creatures, odd weapons made out of animal bones and beautiful scenery straight out of an acid trip.Despite all of that oddity though, the game itself is rather easy to get your head around. It's a first person fighter based around punches, kicks, combos, timing and defensive tactics over super moves or memorizing long combos. You will occasionally find weapons which you can use ranging from giant bone swords. to dual fish pistols. to even a really cool rifle made of bone and animal parts. You can use these pretty much for the entirety of a fight as they have infinite ammo (Unlike in Zeno Clash 2), but despite the occasional mandatory weapon section that betrays the game's source engine roots, Zeno Clash is still very much a first person brawler. The combat feels straight up visceral and impactful with just about every swing, block or throw you make. At times it feels a tad sluggish, The combat is fun, but my favorite element of the (admittedly linear) game is exploring this absolutely crazy world. What's interesting about Zeno Clash's setting is that it doesn't seem to be just contrived of an acid trip, genuine world building has been done here and it shows. Areas range from market towns full of thieves to outlands full of sky high elephant-giraffe-anteater-things, to a few areas I would actually rather not spoil, but every one feels fleshed out and varied.Did I mention the game is gorgeous by the way, even now? Colors seem to fade, merge and pop in a way only water color paintings can. This game has some of the prettiest skyboxes I've ever seen, especially for a source game. Overall, the art design is rather excellent. Just about every character, weapon, and creature feels perfectly in line with game's oddball style.It is the first game by an indie studio, so it's not without its rough spots. The voice actor for Deadra isn't all that great, small parts of the combat like recoveries feel a little sluggish, and the limitations of the source engine occasionally crop up, like rather small levels and loading screens halfway through areas. The fish pistols have this odd bug that still has yet to be fixed where the bottom row of bullet indicators is cut in half on the interface. The FOV is non-adjustable, although this is probably to add to immersion and because it changes mid-game actually mid combat. (This is a game where you can see your own feet, it is aiming for immersion.)Overall, Recommendation: If you even think you might like this, buy it. It's cheap at $10 and is well worth your time to at least play through the campaign once. If you are unsure, wishlist it and wait for a sale, as it usually drops down really, really low in price.If you are wondering about cost to time spent ratio, the campaign is about 4+ hours long, but there's tons to go back and see. There's also a Challenge tower that I didn't bother too much with but you may find intriguing.

Posted: December 12, 2016
												A very strange surreal FPS beat-em-up. Short length, could be played through in its entirety in one sitting, which is perfectly fine in this case. Combat is complex enough to allow for reflex based reactions and fights, but simplsitic enough to where if you can't grasp that, simple stick and moving can win the day too.The entire game's art direction is creative and altogether "Weird", but everything feels weird for a reason - even if that reason is never actually explained to you.While there are some snags to gameplay (being forced to circle strafe "big" enemies to hit them with a club is simply boring, and you do it a good number of times.), it's not a long enough game for it to drag. It answers just enough questions while opening up more, but still feels like it can stand on its own.It's short enough to be an easy recommendation for anyone who likes short, relatively simple action games, or has a taste at all for the weird.

Posted: December 13, 2016
												Now I know I put a thumbs down, but I don't actually think this game is bad. I see lots of potentional in it, but it's very hard to play. I couldn't go more than 2 hours at a time, for it made my head hurt and stomach churn, and I normally don't get sick from playing games. That being said, if you can stand reallly bad camera angles, terrible voice acting, and awkward controls, you'll absolutely love the game. Where this game really shines, is the art style. Now now, I didn't say graphics, I think even for 2009, the graphics is very dated. The art design of the forrest, desert, outfits, and especially guns, are extremely intresting. My personal favorite is the crossbow, the way you reload what I presume to be skulls, and the sight of the weapon itself. Gameplay is extremely repetitive, and although you do go through this weird tutorial thing, you pretty much have access to everything you can do from the get go. I can't say the game isn't fast paced, but I think the best way to put the gameplay is "clonky". This is especially the case when you lock onto an enemy. I pretty much stopped locking to targets because of how hard it is to play, and not in challenging way, but in an impossible kinda way. Another thing I absolutely hate is that there isn't jumping in the game, which bothers me a lot. Although, to be fair, the level design doesn't need jumping. I recommend this for anyone who wants to try something different, but be warned, I'm not sure I mean it in a good way. That's thing, I'm just, not sure about this game. I think with some stealth, more fluidity to movement, better point of view, a more introcet locking system, some form of skill tree to keep gameplay fresh, and maybe some RPG elements, this game would be outstanding. Oh and I almost forgot, better voices and animation, for the love of God I've seen gay TF2 SFMs better than this♥♥♥♥♥♥

Posted: November 25, 2016
Zeno Clash is one of those games that appear just once or twice in a generation. No matter whether you loved it, hated it, or felt nothing at all about it after playing, you remember this game. It's not only the visual design of characters and environments which is truly out of this world; it's not only the quirkiness of characters' voices and personalities and behaviours; it's not just the sinister, disturbing story with its moments of light-hearted insanity; and it's not the peculiar fighting system that will both annoy and delight in equal amounts. Zeno Clash is one of the rare cases where the components intertwine and inexplicably form a whole that's more than the mere sum-of-parts. I can't really find any other game released this side of 2005 that creates so much indescribable and memorable weirdness. ACE Team are masters of such experiences in gaming. That's why Zeno Clash belongs to my personal category of "get copies on as many platforms as possible" - it's totally unique. If life and work permitted, I would replay this as soon as possible.
